The arched ceiling resembles a wide-open sky, complete with ominous gray storm clouds and subdued sunlight that shines fitfully down to the floor below in softly shifting beams. Several low stone benches with curved backs provide comfortable and intimate seating. A narrow staircase leads down to the south.

On the rare occasions when the cultists hosted visitors, they wanted to ensure their guests’ comfort so that they could more easily sway or deceive them. This room’s ceiling had an illusion placed to accurately reflect the sky above Candlemere, but it long ago froze in the current view of a pending rainstorm. Anyone watching the ceiling sees it shudder and loop after a few minutes to repeat the same movements over and over.

The door to the west leads to a short hall with a glyph much like that in area @UUID[.4OF1uIWyLXO4VSKk]. This controls a one-way door leading to area @UUID[.JkCGsov5rkWudJ1D], but unlike the door in area A13, the cultists still use it quite often.

The stairs here descend 100 feet to area @UUID[.nsM73V8Ra1IvLs24].

@UUID[Actor.8gAoSgBJN8QqzP1R]

SIMPLE Hazard 17

As with the trap in area @UUID[.4OF1uIWyLXO4VSKk], misusing the glyph controlling the one-way door triggers a trap to freeze the target in time. However, since this trap has been used so often over the millennia, it’s slightly easier to identify the correct orbs to push. The trap’s Stealth DC is therefore a slightly lower DC 38.

Part 2: The Depth of Fear.name: Part 2: The Depth of Fear
Part 2: The Depth of Fear.text:
The PCs should be 16th level before they attempt to explore the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth. Note that the encounters in this chapter are particularly dangerous, and the PCs are likely to reach 17th level before completing this part. If you’re using milestones for leveling up, consider letting the PCs level up to 17th level the first time they retreat to rest and recover during this chapter rather than waiting for them to defeat Foras at the end.

The deepest levels below Candlemere present a harrowing challenge for a high-level party. While the events that play out in this long-sealed dungeon have very little direct impact on the story of Kingmaker, the potent treasures awaiting discovery within the Spiral will certainly aid the PCs in defending their realm from Nyrissa in the next chapter.

The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth.name: The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth
The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth.text:
Candlemere’s lowest dungeon consists of several rooms built around an enormous spiral engineered by Foras to catch and focus Yog-Sothoth’s gaze, and it is where the Thresholders focus their most important efforts to draw Yog-Sothoth into the Material Plane. In the center of the spiral is a ritual chamber where the cult leader, Foras, works tirelessly at his rituals.

But Foras and his cultists aren’t alone in their endeavor. In the months before the clash with the Pharasmins, Foras reached out to the windswept plateau of Leng, for allies. A group of powerful denizens of Leng answered by sending a delegation of inhuman envoys to aid them, only to become trapped in the dungeon when the Spiral Seal cut off dimensional travel. In that time, the denizens have managed to breach the Spiral Seal only a few times to conjure potent agents from the depths of time itself, but even these powerful hounds of Tindalos found themselves unable to exit the dungeon as long as the Spiral Seal remained.

Fortunately for the cultists, the denizens of Leng are inhumanly patient, and they have been content to merely wait out the Spiral Seal. They’ve taken over the eastern rooms in the lower dungeon, and the cultists are happy to let them have those rooms while they continue to pursue their own goals.

The Helix Theorem

Although the PCs can prevent the Thresholders from finishing their patient endeavor in engineering Yog-Sothoth’s arrival on Golarion by simply killing them all and destroying their work, the very structure of the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth will continue to draw the Outer God’s gaze as long as it remains. Merely knocking over a few walls or blocking a few passages can’t undo the mystical effect the Spiral has imbued the region with; it has existed for so long that its shape is burned into the fabric of reality and the risk of catching Yog-Sothoth’s attention will remain until someone takes specific action to reverse this condition. A PC who has explored the Spiral and succeeds at a @Check[type:occultism|dc:35] or @Check[type:yog-sothoth-lore|dc:33] check realizes the metaphysical danger the lower dungeon poses.

To render the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth entirely harmless, the PCs must discover and perform a mystic rite called the Helix Theorem. The PCs can first learn about this ritual by examining the slate board in area @UUID[.qTHenGfk0sDOKexj], with further information awaiting discovery in area @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9]. In brief, the ritual requires closing a miniature gate icon nine times: once each in areas @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r], @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9], @UUID[.Lax7DSMrgnvjmcyh], @UUID[.0kSqo5oKQtD59pcX], @UUID[.Zh2VM1v7YxAL43Qu], @UUID[.RVeE7HUPof17hEZy], @UUID[.nsM73V8Ra1IvLs24], @UUID[.Y0yPoSJNmiTvJA53], and @UUID[.XYXHryE1sVjrLhUw], in that order. Each time the gate is closed as part of the correct sequence, the icon itself glows with a soothing pale blue light until it is opened again (likely to perform the next closing). If the gate is closed out of sequence, the pale blue light flashes brightly before extinguishing, and the process must be started from the beginning.

The tiny gate must be a specially prepared icon representing the cosmic seal that serves as a boundary between Yog-Sothoth and the Material Plane. The miniature gate in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r] works well for this purpose, although the PCs can prepare their own icon with success on a @Check[type:crafting|dc:38] check. Each time the gate is shut in one of these rooms, the PC performing the ritual must succeed at a @Check[type:occultism|dc:36] check. Other PCs can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW] this check as usual by intoning chants or simply helping to carry the gate. If any of these Occultism checks is failed, the PCs must start again in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]. At the conclusion of the ritual, the miniature gate must be placed—still closed—in the alcove in area @UUID[.XYXHryE1sVjrLhUw] at the very end of the spiral. When the Helix Theorem is successfully performed, the rooms in the lower dungeon twist and flex, shifting through the earth until they all exist along a straight line, rather than a curving spiral. This movement is unnerving but harmless to those in the rooms. The rooms thereafter can’t capture Yog-Sothoth’s attention or open the way for Yog-Sothoth to enter the Material Plane.

While this certainly prevents a potential disaster from destroying the PCs’ kingdom, performing the Helix Theorem here has an unanticipated side effect that the PCs won’t realize until some time later—by performing this rite, they inadvertently bolster their own presence in the flow of time. Any PC who was present below Candlemere when the Helix Theorem is performed gain additional protections once they reach Nyrissa’s @UUID[JournalEntry.GciDhpLFRov9s5Fm.JournalEntryPage.R1rWIW926cn6NfhY].

If the PCs don’t realize the danger posed by the Spiral or fail to perform the Helix Theorem, the long-term effects are up to the GM. Eventually, the Spiral draws other prospective cultists into the chambers; these cultists arrive singly or in small groups but quickly join together to continue the work the Thresholders began. These new cultists might be more powerful or more numerous than those the PCs previously destroyed. The spiral may even draw Yog-Sothoth’s dire gaze, causing spheres of eldritch power to erupt in the region and then begin to pull this part of the Material Plane out of phase with the rest of reality, exacerbating the dangers of the blooms that afflict the PCs’ kingdom at the start of Sound of a Thousand Screams.

Reward: If the PCs successfully complete the Helix Theorem ritual, award them 120 XP.

B1. Washing Station.name: B1. Washing Station
B1. Washing Station.text:
A long trough of clear water lies along the length of the western wall of this room. A narrow, curved alcove extends a few feet into the north wall before ending at a star-shaped symbol. A hall opposite it curves away to the southeast. Stairs ascend steeply to the east.

This chamber is the first of many shrines the cultists regularly use to venerate Yog-Sothoth. Here, at the beginning of the journey along the spiral, the cultists wash their garments and their bodies in icy cold water that is continually cleaned and chilled by a minor magical effect. Cleanliness isn’t particularly important to Yog-Sothoth—who has little care about flesh at all, whether dirty or clean—but the cultists use the cold water scrub to focus their minds on the upcoming portions of the ritual.

The stairs lead up to area @UUID[.mAfM5ivkrUtpWxzO].

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EwgTZBWsc8qKaViP]: Success on a @Check[type:religion|dc:35] check is enough to note that the star-shaped symbol on the alcove wall symbolizes the Outer God Azathoth, seething chaos at the “center of reality.” This symbol serves as the starting point of the ritual spiral that curves throughout this lower level, as the cultists seek to replicate and expand upon this terrifying event.

B2. Chamber of the Worm.name: B2. Chamber of the Worm
B2. Chamber of the Worm.text:
This enormous room contains heaps of glittering stones, each the size of a fist, all haphazardly piled along the west and south walls. A narrow, curved track on the floor leads from the curved hall to the north into the curved hall to the east. In the northeast corner of the room, a terrace-like set of tall stairs leads up to a narrow stone door.

@UUID[Actor.pT5hfxcsG7eV5oxh]

Severe 16

This room serves as the home for an eldritch envoy from the Darklands—a neothelid named Niodrhast. Before the Spiral Seal, Niodrhast came and went via teleportation, and served the Thresholders as a sort of supply route for strange components or other needs. The neothelid went into hibernation soon after the Spiral Seal locked it in place; it wakens from its torpor slowly now that the seal has been broken. It attacks any intruders into this realm at once, but if the PCs are forced to retreat and return, they’ll find Niodrhast has vacated the area, having returned to Denebrum to catch up on the centuries it missed.

@UUID[Actor.GroRcpNkb9F8sVJT]: One of the quartz gems on the floor has a dispelling sliver talisman lodged within it. This treasure is well concealed among the heaps of valueless quartz, however, and a PC who @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU] the piles must succeed at a @Check[type:perception|dc:36|traits:action:search] check to locate it.

B3. Rune-Scribed Room.name: B3. Rune-Scribed Room
B3. Rune-Scribed Room.text:
The walls, floors, and ceiling of this room are inscribed with thousands of tiny runes, each glittering with a pale, cold light like that of a distant star. A staircase ascends to the southwest, and a door stands in the northeast corner. A curved hall exits to the east and another exits to the north. By the runes worn away between those two halls, it’s clear that a significant amount of foot traffic has come and gone between them.

The runes here aren’t magical except for their glow, but they represent thousands of different components of the eldritch worship of Yog-Sothoth. Each rune represents a deeper concept that requires decades of study to understand. The cultists pass into this room as part of their ritual journey along the spiral, choosing a single different rune to stare at and meditate upon each time they come through here.

The door to the northeast leads to a short hallway culminating in a door to area @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9], a room with a similar meditative purpose. Cutting from one of these rooms to the other can be disruptive to meditations, so just inside the hallway near each door, a small metal bell has been rigged to ring when the opposite door is opened, alerting occupants that someone is coming through the hallway. The mechanism that triggers the bells can be spotted before a door is opened with success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check, after which it’s an easy @Check[type:thievery|dc:25|traits:action:disable-device] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6] the bell.

The staircase leads up to area @UUID[.YDka3Bsn8Byl9TIL].

B4. Cold Praise.name: B4. Cold Praise
B4. Cold Praise.text:
This long room has two curving hallways exiting from the north and south walls of its western end and two steep stairways descending from the north and south walls of its eastern end. At the east end of the room, a rounded alcove shows ever-shifting shapes in a vibrant blue color.

The shapes in the east alcove are words in Aklo, constantly shifting and changing to form praises to Yog-Sothoth and aphorisms about the Outer God’s eventual return when the stars are right and the cosmic gate is opened. Anyone who enters this room must read aloud from the script or face a debilitating magical trap. The visitors from Leng who occupy areas @UUID[.oIZS4kHetJvOBuNq]–@UUID[.YM5DVrfs7Hyb4fOJ] to the east don’t bother on the occasions they pass through here since they’re immune to cold.

@UUID[Actor.oqlZNnsV8XMGn7JN]

Severe 16

Any creature who spends more than 1 round in this room and doesn’t read aloud one of the phrases in Aklo writhing above the alcove causes the trap to trigger.

B5. The Howling Room.name: B5. The Howling Room
B5. The Howling Room.text:
The noise of howling wind is obvious to any hearing creature from the stairs leading down into this chamber.

A few stone biers are the only furnishings in this room. An alcove to the southeast emits a constant howl of wind that blows around the room. The wind isn’t particularly strong, but gouges on the walls indicate that it must have been blowing ceaselessly for many years. A staircase ascending from the south wall is the room’s only exit.

The alcove emits a constant howling wind that is magically contained to this room. The wind originates from hundreds of tiny holes at the rear of the alcove, but its source is a distant nameless world where ceaseless storms howl. The cultists sometimes meditated in this room, listening for insights into creation from the ceaseless wind.

The wind imposes a –2 circumstance penalty on auditory Perception checks and on attack rolls for ranged physical attacks, such as arrows. Unprotected flames in the room are instantly blown out. The room is difficult terrain for creatures that are Flying.

  • @UUID[Actor.bwEYizrdHs8lmvxE]
  • @UUID[Actor.sw32QdZlsWnmWaVY]

Encounter

Severe 16

As the Leng envoys found this room reminded them of their windswept home, Foras graciously allowed them to use it as their private chamber. One envoy is currently here while the other is being interviewed by cultists in area @UUID[.Zh2VM1v7YxAL43Qu].

That single Leng envoy and a mastiff of Tindalos are enjoying the blowing wind. They realize that anyone they don’t recognize must be an enemy of the cult, and they hope to curry favor with Foras by eliminating them quickly. The Leng envoy fights to the death, but the mastiff of Tindalos, recognizing that the Spiral Seal is no more since the PCs obviously made it inside, flees via Angled Entry if reduced to fewer than 30 HP.

B6. Garden.name: B6. Garden
B6. Garden.text:
This enormous natural cavern is nearly a hundred feet long and sixty feet wide. It is overgrown with a profusion of fungi and strange ferns that grow to an immense size despite the lack of natural light. The floor of the chamber is unpleasantly spongy and gives off a putrid smell. A small stone shed stands at the south end of the cavern, nearly overgrown with vegetation.

The cultists discovered this enormous cavern while constructing the lower dungeon and use it to grow fungi, herbs, and insects the hermeticists use in their experiments. Otherwise, the cultists leave the area alone—they don’t need to eat and therefore don’t require sustenance themselves.

@UUID[Actor.sw32QdZlsWnmWaVY]

Severe 16

The Leng envoys asked for this room for their mastiffs, and Foras was glad to provide it to the otherworldly visitors. The mastiffs eagerly attack any intruders, fighting to the death.

B7. Overgrown Shed.name: B7. Overgrown Shed
B7. Overgrown Shed.text:
This small stone shed was already part of this cavern when the cultists constructed the Candlemere dungeons millennia ago. Even then, it was already impossibly old, its stone riddled with the vegetation that grew up around it and its stone corners crumbled and rounded with age. The stone door leading into the shed sits slightly off its rusted pivot pin and requires a @Check[type:athletics|dc:36|traits:action:force-open] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx].

@UUID[Actor.uQbzVX7DWDbxLONd]

Simple Hazard 19

The interior of the shed is dark and featureless. It is also totally devoid of any plant life that grows with such profusion outside of it—a side effect of the fact that the shed’s interior is infused with destructive emotional energy, for this location in the spiral has become a sort of supernatural sump for the excess of awfulness shed over the past thousands of years by the trapped, ageless cultists.

@UUID[Actor.eOC3K7034tHb9Zxt]: Even a cursory examination of the shed’s interior reveals a small pile of rags and scraps, as if a destitute person left their tattered clothes in the corner before vanishing. Among these mysterious rags is a dread blindfold.

B8. Lecture Room.name: B8. Lecture Room
B8. Lecture Room.text:
This L-shaped room has the curved hallway arcing through its center. A raised platform stands at each end of the room, and a few heavy stone stools are clustered around the platform to the east. A door stands in the west wall.

This is the primary meeting place for the Thresholders, and it’s where Foras gathers them together to make pronouncements, issue changes in the devotion rituals, or publicly punish wrongdoers.

  • @UUID[Actor.bwEYizrdHs8lmvxE]
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]

Encounter

Severe 16

The current occupants are a Leng envoy and two disciples named Brulen and Ferandir. The disciples have been tasked with finding out more from the Leng envoy about how to open wide the cosmic gate to let Yog-Sothoth through. The disciples worry that because the envoy is just so much smarter and more devout than they are, their relative ignorance will lead to punishment. Brulen and Ferandir each keep trying to show that they understand more of what the envoy is saying than the other, when in fact neither has any idea. They find the whole interview particularly frustrating, and the envoy, who enjoys tormenting the disciples with their ignorance, has no intention of letting the interview end anytime soon.

If this group becomes aware of intruders, the envoy simply sits back and opines in Aklo, “Now you can show me what you know.” Happy to be doing something they’re good at, the disciples rush into combat. The envoy hangs back, supporting the disciples with its spells if it seems like it won’t put itself in any danger by doing so.

The envoy ceases hostilities if the disciples are defeated, offering to answer any questions the PCs have. Instead of providing detailed answers, however, it provides only basic facts that it assumes the PCs already know, such as the tenets of the cult and the powers that different types of cultists can bring to bear. The envoy freely admits that aiding the cultists in bringing Yog-Sothoth through the mystical gate to rend this world suits its own purposes, although the envoys themselves aren’t particularly devoted to Yog-Sothoth. The envoy might let slip some information that fills in gaps in the PCs’ knowledge, such as that Foras is the leader of the cult, that he works at the center of the spiral, or even that a rite called the Helix Theorem can turn Yog-Sothoth’s attention away from Candlemere. During the course of the interrogation, the envoy gives up its strangely flawless Leng rubies, surrendering them as spoils of war or even hinting that they hold magical power. If the envoy can convince the PCs to demand the rubies instead of merely accepting them, all the better. The envoy then tries to use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9BnhadUO8FMLmeZ3] on a PC with one of the rubies and learn more about them. Ultimately, the envoy plans to betray the PCs, but if it can do so when they’ve let their guard down, that works just as well. Once it springs this trap, the envoy fights until destroyed.

B9. Storage Room.name: B9. Storage Room
B9. Storage Room.text: This room contains supplies the cultists either haven’t gotten around to fixing or only use for special occasions. They include stone chairs, broken alchemical equipment, moldy leather, and dull weapons. A single skeleton is hidden behind some of the furniture here; this cultist irritated the others so badly that, in defiance of Foras’s orders, they killed him and stashed his body here.

B10. Mortification Room.name: B10. Mortification Room
B10. Mortification Room.text:
Racks around this room contain scourges, wide-bladed knives, and sickles. All are crusted with blood, which pools on the floor beneath them. A door leads west, and a curving hall cuts through this room from east to south.

The cultists engage in ritual mortification of the flesh as they travel through this room in their devotional journey. This isn’t a requirement of Yog-Sothoth but a requirement of Foras himself: the sadistic cult leader likes to think of his cultists regularly flaying themselves out of dedication to his twisted leadership alone. To encourage compliance with a step that the cultists all know isn’t doctrinally required, Foras placed a magical alarm in this room. Whenever any creature enters this room and hasn’t inflicted at least 1 Hit Point of damage on itself with a melee weapon (whether one of the weapons here or a weapon brought into this room) within 1 minute, chimes ring in areas @UUID[.e2mBA5PYWVyrn3Cz] and @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]. These chimes also ring if a creature leaves the room without injury before 1 minute has elapsed, preventing anyone from simply hurrying through this room without performing the requisite self-mortification.

If the chimes ring, the cultists in area @UUID[.e2mBA5PYWVyrn3Cz] realize that someone hasn’t performed the appropriate ritual step and they eagerly pile out of the room to capture the shirker. Once they realize the alarm was due to an intruder rather than to someone failing to fulfill the ritual obligation, they attack. Foras hears the chime in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r], but he has faith that his cultists will catch the wrongdoer on his behalf, so he doesn’t respond personally.

Success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:36] check is enough to notice the subtle magical energies infusing this room that comprise the alarm, and any spell that pinpoints magical auras reveals the alarm automatically. Once it’s revealed, it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6] with a @Check[type:thievery|dc:35] (legendary) check or by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG] (9th level, counteract DC 36).

@UUID[Actor.CZz82l5EK3D5CQJj]: The daggers, scourges, and sickles in this room don’t have any particular value, with the exception of a high-grade orichalcum sickle engraved with prayers to Yog-Sothoth.

B11. Lower Bunk Room.name: B11. Lower Bunk Room
B11. Lower Bunk Room.text:
Sleeping niches are carved into the walls of this room at varying levels. A thin mist fills this room.

This bunk room is similar to area @UUID[.iGCiO2WLCCxc103m], but this room has niches carved into the walls rather than slabs protruding from them. The same type of worn leather pallet lies in each niche.

  • @UUID[Actor.3kyS4KzEmG8Eyl4N]
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]

Encounter

Severe 16

A stern hermeticist named Surebna and four disciples are currently resting here, although they are quick to leap into action upon any sign of trouble. This room is too small for all these combatants to effectively fight at once, so the disciples work to push foes into area @UUID[.0kSqo5oKQtD59pcX] where they have more room to move around. The four disciples fight to the death, but Surebna has a bit more self-preservation: he retreats to area @UUID[.Lax7DSMrgnvjmcyh] if reduced to fewer than 40 Hit Points, hoping to rouse the guardians there against intruders.

B12. Black Sand Cavern.name: B12. Black Sand Cavern
B12. Black Sand Cavern.text:
The door leading into this room from area @UUID[.Y0yPoSJNmiTvJA53] is covered with a large drift of rubble; opening it from that side requires a successful @Check[type:athletics|dc:36] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx].

This natural cavern is heaped with drifts of rubble and gravel. A track through the rubble connects a curved hallway entering the room from the north to another curved hallway entering from the east.

This natural cavern was here when Foras and the Thresholders made the spiral, and they used the chamber as a place to dump a lot of the loose stone from building the spiral itself, filling in much of what was once a larger pit to the south.

@UUID[Actor.hD8Su0awrJYwmDXh]

Severe 16

A trio of alien entities–quelaunts—has dwelt in this cavern since long before the Thresholders arrived. The quelaunts initially attacked the Thresholders, but they broke off hostilities as they recognized certain familiar qualities in the cult’s leader. Since then, the three quelaunts have remained here feeding on the ambient emotions of the place. They find the frustrations, hopes, and disappointments of creatures who do not age to be quite delicious, but they won’t skip the opportunity to feed on more traditional emotions the PCs may bring with them. The quelaunts fight to the death.

B13. Acolyte Alcoves.name: B13. Acolyte Alcoves
B13. Acolyte Alcoves.text:
This room is brightly lit, and its light is evident from down the curved hall leading to it.

Two large, rounded alcoves stand next to each other at the south end of this room. Both blaze with light emanating from several unnerving pinpoints that shift and move around. Just visible in the glare from the alcoves is a door leading east. The curving hall cuts through the northwest corner of this chamber.

This chamber provides a vision of the stars closest to Yog-Sothoth’s gate. By carefully interpreting the psychic emanations from the Outer God, the cultists believe that they have managed to reconstruct the stellar location of the cosmic gate barring it from the Material Plane. Here, the cultists must meditate upon the lights to find esoteric patterns that might aid in opening the gate further. Staring directly into the light is painful after a long period of time for those who still have eyes, but the cultists feel no such pain now that they’ve moved on to the benefits of unseen sight.

@UUID[Actor.htHgsx1COWOfhE3D] (2)

Severe 16

Two mystics named Tolas and Noliskur are currently here. They each have a lightweight brass tablet and a stylus to record observations they make as they work backward through the Helix Theorem, calculating how to reverse the theorem to strengthen, rather than weaken, Yog-Sothoth’s gaze into Candlemere.

If the mystics have reason to expect anyone intruding on their mediations, they prepare to chastise whomever arrives. If they identify the PCs as intruders from the surface, the mystics do their best to dispatch them as quickly as possible.

Treasure: The brass tablets the mystics carry provide a great deal of specific detail about the Helix Theorem. Although it’s clear from their notes that the cultists were trying to discover a way to reverse the theorem, it’s useful for the PCs to see the detailed ritual notes about unshackling Yog-Sothoth’s attention from Candlemere. By reviewing the mystics’ tablets, the PCs can learn all the necessary steps for performing the Helix Theorem ritual (see @UUID[.ZPtDIkEsiwPp3Gem]).

B14. Ritual Chamber.name: B14. Ritual Chamber
B14. Ritual Chamber.text:
The large chamber has two parts. The narrower room to the east is square and has a few tables and workbenches around it. The spherical room to the west is studded with pinprick lights like distant stars. Chalk lines connect many of these stars together in constellations that defy ordinary geometry. Dividing the two halves of this room is an archway etched with eldritch symbols that glow with a cold light and emit a low moan, like wind blowing past the threshold of a partially opened door.

This two-part chamber is where the cult leader Foras has worked so tirelessly to bring Yog-Sothoth into the Material Plane to lay waste to it. Foras believes that, in doing so, he alone will be the chosen and only survivor that the terrible Yog-Sothoth will spare. The workbenches all contain various occult devices, small models, and slate boards containing astrological calculations. The chalk marks in the spherical area at the heart of the spiral are also his, but they are creations of his own wicked mind and don’t follow any usual astronomical logic. It’s impossible to tell from these materials how close Foras is to success, but the cold wind blowing from the rune indicates that Yog-Sothoth’s presence is indeed near.

  • @UUID[Actor.2mkfF43tP8IGVfBz]
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]

Encounter

Severe 17

Foras is here, accompanied by four disciples who take measurements, transcribe notes, and otherwise assist Foras in his abstruse labor.

When confronted with intruders, Foras’s first action is to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx], then he moves into an advantageous tactical position behind his disciples to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.uEyfLoFQsRKBRIcB], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.FmNDwqMEjeTEGPrY], or other useful spells to impede the PCs. When time starts again, he Sustains these Spells or casts others to keep the PCs off balance. He doesn’t mind catching his disciples in the area of his spells if it means hindering the PCs as well. As he fights, Foras shrieks about how his efforts to call Yog-Sothoth cannot be stopped and that the cosmic gate will soon open wide. Foras and his disciples fight to the death; if he’s reduced to fewer than 20 hit points and no disciples yet live, Foras destroys his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.6m9niDjhA6tBfp5x] to unleash a blast of energy.

@UUID[Actor.mxGasmiHaza9lkME]: One of the items on the worktable is a very realistic miniature gate with symbols like those found in this room. No larger than a human hand, the gate has a stone door that swings open and closed. This icon is worth 10 gp for its craftsmanship, but the PCs are likely to find it particularly useful if they’ve learned about the Helix Theorem. The other materials on the worktable are mostly valueless tinkerings, despite the many long years that went into their creation. However, a vial containing a major cognitive mutagen lies amid the jumble.

Concluding the Chapter.name: Concluding the Chapter
Concluding the Chapter.text:
After the PCs have defeated Foras and the cultists, their plan to open the gate to attract Yog-Sothoth no longer threatens the region. Any Leng envoys who still live decide to retreat to Leng for the time being, although they’re certain to spend their time in that distant plane advancing plots that spell ill for Golarion. If the PCs retain any of their strange rubies, they might become the focus of these plots.

The chambers below Candlemere remain, and the passage of time swiftly expunges any lingering influence the cult may have once had in the region. Any of the undead Pharasmins who were bound to the upper halls of the dungeon finally collapse to dust, their souls moving on for judgment. If in your campaign, one of the PCs or a significant NPC is a worshipper of Pharasma, you could use this development as an opportunity for the party to perform an absolution for these ancient worshipers of Pharasma—a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Dbd5W6G8U2vzWolN] ritual or the like will certainly suffice for this. To the Lady of Graves herself, the passage of time is largely irrelevant, and while these doomed Pharasmins abandoned their lives, souls, and faith in order to stand against the cult, the amount of time their souls remained in stasis in their undead shells did not concern her—judgment comes to all in time. But this doesn’t mean she won’t appreciate the PCs’ actions in defeating Foras and his cult.

As such, even if the PCs don’t perform absolution rites for the graveknights, the Lady of Graves makes sure to reward the PCs for their acts. She grants a moderate boon to every character as soon as the cult is defeated, granting them greater mastery over the energies of life and death. To the characters, this boon manifests as a potent dream the next time they sleep, wherein they see themselves standing before Pharasma’s throne not as souls but as living creatures. With a mercurial smile, Pharasma traces the spiral of her symbol on the PCs’ brow with her fingertip, and when that character wakes they gain the full benefits of her divine intercession.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.boons-and-curses.Item.xrSgGobm5QtTcABQ] causes a character’s Strikes to deal 1 positive damage to undead. Any of the character’s spells that deal positive damage to undead gain a +1 status bonus to damage per spell level, and spells that heal the living gain a +1 status bonus to the Hit Points restored per level. In addition, these PCs will find that as they age, they remain fit and hale and healthy—old age will hold no decline for them. These particular benefits are unlikely to be realized in most Kingmaker campaigns, of course, but mentioning this to the PCs when they finish the Adventure Path can be an additional emotional reward for a job well done. Of course, when the heroes’ time comes, they still pass on to the River of Souls—Pharasma’s boon does not offer immortality, only a slight reprieve of the aches and pains along the way.

On the other hand, if the PCs didn’t complete the Helix Theorem, they might face further dangers from the ominous spiral beneath the Stolen Lands, and in time, another cult may arrive to take advantage of the site’s eldritch nature. The eyes of Yog-Sothoth are many, and cultists of the Lurker at the Threshold continually strive to open the gate for their dread god. If the PCs aren’t quite high enough level to withstand the dangers that they’ll face as Kingmaker’s endgame begins in the next chapter, consider having them face additional perils as Yog-Sothoth’s influence spreads throughout their kingdom, be it in the form of additional dangerous Kingdom events or in the shape of new adventures of your own design.

Part 4: Infiltration.name: Part 4: Infiltration
Part 4: Infiltration.text:
The PCs (and their kingdom) should be 14th level before attempting to liberate Pitax.

As the War of the River Kings progresses, King Irovetti’s fear causes him to seclude himself in his palace. If Pitax is doing poorly in the war, his primary concern is retribution from the PCs; if his armies are doing well, he instead worries that public appearances will expose him to potential assassins. In either case, Irovetti is readying for a direct attack—but he isn’t preparing for the PCs to stoke insurrection among his people.

Many of Pitax’s citizens rankle and chafe at their king’s rule, but on their own they lack the gumption, outrage, and bravery to stand up to him. With some careful work, canny PCs can turn Pitax’s citizens against their king and weaken his hold on them, making the inevitable confrontation against him in his palace less dangerous.

The City of Pitax.name: The City of Pitax
The City of Pitax.text:
Pitax

Settlement 10

  • CN
  • City

Government King (overlord)

Population 5,781 (4,706 humans, 320 halflings, 260 gnomes, 200 half-elves, 100 elves, 60 goblins, 95 dwarves, 40 other)

Languages Common, Elven, Halfling, Gnome, Hallit

Religions Calistria, Desna

Threats Criminals, political corruption, the PCs’ kingdom

Performer’s City Pitax prides itself on the diversity of its arts and entertainments, but at the same time has a legacy of artists and performers being unjustly persecuted for their work. Treat Pitax as a 14th-level settlement for determining the availability of jobs for Performance and art-themed Crafting or Lore attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QyzlsLrqM0EEwd7j]. If a PC critically fails at an attempt to Earn Income using these skills, they have angered someone enough that repercussions will occur—be it an arrest by Pitax Wardens or even an assassination attempt by an outraged former fan of their work.

Annamede Belavarah (CN female human bard 13) Famous comedian and agitator against Irovetti

Atlee Quinge (NG female human bard 7) Director of the Red Crescent Troupe

Castruccio Irovetti (CE male human bard 16) King of Pitax

Drey Yarness (CN male human cleric of Calistria 10) High priest of Calistria

Eliste Strocalle (NE female human rogue 8) Leader of the Strocalle Bandit House

Gasperre Liacenza (N male human aristocrat 5) Leader of the Liacenza Bandit House

Ghare Leotos (CG male human cleric of Desna 6) High priest of Desna

Jhofre Vascari (LN male human rogue 9) Leader of the Vascari Bandit House

Kharne Vareel (NE male gnome rogue 13) Ringleader of the Dealers of Pitax

Salvarri Cattanei (N male human bard 8) Leader of the Cattanei Bandit House

For nearly 400 years, Pitax remained a relatively small and unassuming city. Though marred by strife with neighboring nations, and even suffering some scars from a brief but brutal civil war, Pitax always stood as a sanctuary of sorts at the edge of the Stolen Lands. With the arrival of just one man only six years ago, however, this legacy changed. As the bandit king Castruccio Irovetti took control of Pitax, the city began to mirror his dark and brutal personality, becoming a force to be reckoned with in the River Kingdoms and drawing the ire and envy of the lands surrounding it.

By far, the most startling change made to Pitax by the decree of Irovetti has been his ham-fisted attempt to focus upon the fine arts. Determined to make Pitax a center of genteel refinement and culture, Irovetti ordered the construction of the Red Crescent theater, which became the cornerstone of other revitalized parts of Pitax. The city grew, attracting many actors, musicians, and other artists, causing the city’s coffers to swell with fresh gold. But by bringing in so many new souls, Pitax suddenly found a sinister, unsavory element becoming a part of its very core.

The presence of so many bards and storytellers from so many places has made the city a haven for secrets, rumors, tall tales, and occasionally even the truth. If one seeks information that might be little more than whispers and dust, Pitax might be the place to unearth clues. What sages don’t know, Pitax often does. The only trick to finding rare secrets in Pitax—secrets that could possibly lead to treasures or dooms beyond imagination—is knowing where to look.

That, and perhaps living long enough to escape with these secrets.

Liberating Pitax.name: Liberating Pitax
Liberating Pitax.text:
If the PCs have allied with Pitaxian rebels such as Ilora, these advisors impress upon the PCs that most of Pitax’s citizens are innocents caught up in their king’s agenda, and they strongly recommend against attacking or besieging the city. These sources suggest that once Pitax’s field armies are defeated and Avinash’s forces are routed, King Irovetti’s bravado will falter. At the same time, clandestine infiltrations into Pitax to destabilize his support from within can strike a devastating blow to Irovetti’s plans. Through a combination of defeating his field armies and turning factions within the city against him, the PCs can break the morale of the Pitaxian army and force King Irovetti to retreat into his palace, whereupon he’ll be cornered. These allies point to Irovetti’s legendary stubbornness as another great disadvantage, for he won’t consider fleeing “his” kingdom as long as the chance to defeat the PCs exists.

Liberation Activities

Pitax is a nation united under a competent and canny leader. Irovetti’s people may not love him, and his eccentricities regarding the arts frustrate and bewilder many, but they’d rather have him on their side than against them... at least until his bold and daring war of conquest threatens to bankrupt the kingdom and bring it from prosperity to ruin.

If the PCs wish to preserve the city, respect its citizens, and potentially set themselves up as saviors instead of proving that they’re the warmongers Irovetti’s propaganda portrays them as, they’ll need to pursue more subtle tactics than throwing armies against the city walls. They can pursue this goal using Liberation activities. Doing so awards Liberation Points (or penalizes them in the case of failures). Liberation Points can also be gained or (more often) lost through other developments, as summarized in Liberation Point Adjustments below.

Liberation activities play out in Exploration mode. Unless otherwise specified, a Liberation activity takes 3 hours to resolve, so during a typical day (which assumes the PCs spend 8 hours resting, 1 hour taking daily preparations, and 3 hours eating, relaxing, and potentially performing other exploration activities) a PC can attempt four Liberation activities.

Liberation Point Adjustments

Each time one of the following events occurs, adjust the PCs’ current Liberation Point (LP) total as indicated.

The PCs slay a Pitax civilian: –5 LP

One of Pitax’s field armies is defeated: +2 LP

One of Pitax’s field armies wins a battle: –2 LP

The PCs cause public destruction in Pitax: –1 to –5 LP (varies, with examples including –1 for minor vandalism or –5 for destroying a building)

The PCs do not Lie Low after an encounter with a Warden patrol: –1d4+2 LP

The PCs attack Pitax with an army: LP can no longer be gained for 1 month

The primary way in which the PCs earn Liberation Points is by discovering and pursuing opportunities keyed to specific locations in Pitax. A PC can certainly discover a location’s liberation activities by stumbling on the location and asking the right questions, but it’s perhaps more efficient for a PC to use the Seek Opportunity activity instead to learn about these specific opportunities.

Initial Liberation Points: If the PCs won the Rushlight Tournament, their fame precedes them and they begin with 6 Liberation Points. If they made second place, they start with 3 Liberation Points. Otherwise, they start with 1 Liberation Point. Add 2 Liberation points for each battle the PCs have won against any of Pitax’s field armies, and subtract 2 for each such battle lost.

30+ Liberation Points: Once the PCs accumulate at least 30 Liberation Points, the atmosphere on Pitax’s streets grows very decidedly anti-Irovetti. As long as the PCs’ Liberation Point total remains at 30 or higher, no Warden patrols are encountered on the streets of Pitax, and the number of guards and defenses present at the palace is reduced as detailed in Part 5. Once Irovetti is defeated, it will be much easier for the PCs to bring Pitax into their kingdom if they have at least 30 Liberation Points (see the end of this chapter).

0 Liberation Points: Liberation Points can’t be reduced below 0. As long as the PCs are at 0 Liberation Points, they suffer a –4 status penalty on all checks made to resolve Liberation activities. If something would normally cause Liberation Points to go below 0, the PCs are instead confronted by two Warden patrols (a Severe 14 encounter) or increase the status penalty to Liberation checks to –4 for the next 24 hours (GM’s choice). If the PCs are at 0 Liberation Points in their quest to free Pitax when a Kingdom turn begins, enough volunteers join the Pitaxian army that a new @UUID[JournalEntry.yGGSDRma9yTWwdeo.JournalEntryPage.3qLrv7twWmOnexiT] field army encamps in a hex of the GM’s choice along the border of the PCs’ kingdom.

Liberation Activities.name: Liberation Activities
Liberation Activities.text:
Liberation activities can be taken at any point, and do not need to be “unlocked” by visiting a specific location in Pitax. When the PCs first begin to work at liberating the city, you should provide them with a list of all of these activities so they’ll know what options are available for them to pursue. Liberation points may only be earned once per success or critical success, regardless of how many attempts are made.

Clandestine Activity

  • Exploration
  • Move

You spend time pursuing urban activities in Pitax that don’t directly impact the city’s liberation. When you shop for items, gather information, craft, attempt to earn income, or take other Exploration or Downtime pursuits, you automatically attract the attention of a Warden patrol unless you make that activity clandestine. To do so, attempt a Deception, Society, or Stealth check to trick observers, appear as if you belong, or simply avoid notice.

  • Critical Success The activity takes no more time than normal, and you avoid attracting the attention of any Pitax Wardens.

  • Success The activity takes twice as long to finish, but you avoid attracting the attention of any Pitax Wardens.

  • Failure After spending half the time on the activity, you attract the attention of a Warden patrol. If you immediately halt your activity and do not complete it, you avoid a confrontation with the Pitax Wardens. If you don’t stop your activity, this result becomes a Critical Failure.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but you cannot avoid the Pitax Wardens, and have an encounter with a Warden patrol.

Gain Faction Favor

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration

You spend time speaking with the leaders of a faction you’ve made contact with, and you attempt to gain favor with them so that when the time comes to take control of Pitax, they can aid in spreading your influence and helping to get the citizens of Pitax on your side. When you seek to Gain Faction Favor, you can always do so by attempting a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:34] check. You can also attempt a different DC 30 skill check or Lore check as noted in the location entry for that faction.

  • Critical Success The faction is impressed with you. Gain 2 LP, and you may use that faction’s headquarters as a safe haven in Pitax—any Exploration or Downtime activities that don’t require open travel in the city can be performed at this safe haven without needing to be a Clandestine Activity.

  • Success The faction agrees to support you. Gain 1 LP.

  • Failure You fail to gain favor with the faction, but you can try again the next day.

  • Critical Failure You insult or antagonize the faction. Lose 1 LP; you cannot attempt to gain favor again with this faction for 1 month.

Lie Low

  • Exploration

When Pitax Wardens grow too suspicious or up their patrols, all PCs can spend 3 hours deliberately avoiding confrontation, hiding, and keeping an eye out for when the coast is clear to continue exploration. If you aren’t in a safe spot (such as a refuge provided by a faction, or a location the GM has decided is secluded enough) you must attempt a @Check[type:stealth|dc:30] check (you can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.tfa4Sh7wcxCEqL29] for this check). If you are in a safe spot, no roll is needed; you automatically achieve a Success result.

  • Success Things calm down on the streets enough that you can go back to pursuing Liberation activities.

  • Failure Things remain tense, but if you Lie Low again for your next action, you achieve a Success automatically even if you aren’t in a safe spot.

  • Critical Failure You’ve been found or ratted out! All PCs have an encounter with a Warden patrol.

Pursue Opportunity

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration

Most locations in Pitax detail opportunities for the party to earn Liberation Points. The details of each varies according to the location, but the mechanics remain the same. Once you’ve discovered an opportunity, attempt a DC 32 check using the skill called for by that opportunity. You can continue to Pursue an Opportunity multiple times until you critically succeed at it, but only earn Liberation Points once the first time you succeed or critically succeed at this activity.

  • Critical Success Earn 2 Liberation Points and gain an additional minor boon or advantage as detailed in the location’s Opportunity entry.

  • Success Earn 1 Liberation Point.

  • Critical Failure Lose 1 Liberation Point.

Research Faction

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration
  • Secret

Once you discover one of Pitax’s factions, you can spend time gathering information and investigating that faction to learn more about it. To do so, attempt a @Check[type:society|dc:32] check. Unless you have a critical failure, you learn basic information about the faction, including the name of its leader, the location of its headquarters, and a bit about their goals.

  • Critical Success You learn what the faction’s associated skill is, along with additional information that gives you a +2 circumstance bonus on checks made to Gain Favor with that Faction.

  • Success You learn what the faction’s associated skill is.

  • Critical Failure As success, but the information you learn is false.

Seek Opportunity

  • Exploration
  • Move

You ask around town, eavesdrop on conversations, and keep an eye on the streets to search for opportunities to liberate Pitax. When you Seek Opportunity, choose a spot on the map of Pitax, then attempt a @Check[type:perception|dc:34] check or a @Check[type:society|dc:30] check as your character Seeks Opportunities nearby.

  • Critical Success You learn of the two closest opportunities to the position you chose. The GM reveals the location of these opportunities on the map; you must still travel to that location and investigate on site to determine what sort of opportunity exists. If no more opportunities exist in Pitax to discover, you learn that fact instead.

  • Success As critical success, but only the one closest opportunity.

  • Critical Failure You attract too much attention, and if your next activity within 1,500 feet of the spot you chose is anything other than Lie Low, that activity attracts a Warden patrol.

Exploring Pitax.name: Exploring Pitax
Exploring Pitax.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.YLAttheRk2UT3x1B]

A map of the city of Pitax.

A hundred years ago, Pitax endured a small but bloody civil war in which the northern part of the kingdom seceded and formed a small realm known as Corvenn. The violence between Pitax and Corvenn culminated in an incident known as the Deafening Flames, when rebels from Corvenn torched the southern wall of Pitax and razed the southern half of the city. Though Corvenn and Pitax eventually resolved their differences and merged back into a single River Kingdom, the damage was done. The southern half of Pitax lay in ruin for decades, just a pile of rubble and lingering ashes.

Recent additions to the entire city can be found in the form of statues, particularly gargoyles. Commissioned by Irovetti himself to mimic the historic pomp of aged southern cities, most of these statues are disgusting or crude works of monsters or human figures—sometimes both. Many of the gargoyles that sit ominously atop rooftops in Pitax—especially those closest to the palace where Irovetti resides—are works of genuine quality, but over the past few years, more sloppy and crude efforts have spread across Pitax like a disease.

The wharfside of Troutmouth is a strange mix of hardworking warehouse workers living with their families and freebooting sailors who drift in and out of the city with their ships. Though this often leads to loud and boisterous conflicts between the two groups in the wee hours of the morning, both the workers and the sailors share a grudging respect for one another. The two groups are unified by a shared loathing for the Bandit Houses, which they believe to be rich, selfish, and indifferent to their problems. Wooden warehouses standing amid smaller wooden buildings line the docks of Troutmouth. Of these smaller buildings, most are old and weatherworn, with even the newer buildings bearing obvious water damage from the Pitax River’s occasional floods. Muddy roads crisscross their way through Troutmouth, but these slowly give way to cobblestone streets as they finally enter the Shattered Ward and the heart of Pitax.

Long the spiritual heart of Pitax, the Shattered Ward grew from the remnants of the bandit keep built during the city’s earliest days. This is where most merchants and travelers conduct their business. Its streets are the busiest, its buildings the largest, and its shadows the most likely to hide secrets and dangers. Large buildings made of dark limestone, some several stories in height, rise throughout this area, surrounding the Common Square like stones ringing a campfire. A large wall known as the Inner Fortress, made from limestone of a lighter hue, runs along the southern border of the Shattered Ward.

Old and new gates alike lead from that wall into the New Ruins, the part of Pitax that was once overrun and destroyed during the city’s bloody civil war a century earlier. New stone roads and small stone buildings, built from the remains of the great towers that once stood proudly over the city in earlier days, stand amid the genuine ruins in this partially rebuilt sector. When Irovetti ascended to power, he proceeded to take ownership of this area that had long lain fallow, and he began rebuilding it according to his own garish tastes. The Red Crescent Theater and the Academy of Grand Arts became the heart of the revitalized west end of Pitax. Though both were built ostensibly for the purpose of making Pitax a haven for fine art, Irovetti had a shrewder purpose in mind: attracting builders, artists, and merchants, and, by extension, more money. The New Ruins now presents a half-realized appearance, with the sculpted stone facades of buildings along the Inner Fortress turning to carved wood and eventually to plain timber near the edge of town. At its farthest reaches, public funding and interest waned, leaving several blocks of aging rubble and dangerous, burnt-out frames available for whatever squatters or dangerous creatures dare to claim them.

Warden Patrols

Low 14

Trios of Pitax Wardens patrol the city streets, and they confront the PCs if they notice them. Generally, such a confrontation occurs only when the PCs fail or critically fail at certain Liberation activities, but at your option (such as if the PCs make an extremely public appearance), they are confronted by a Warden patrol that attacks them at once. If characters wish to escape the Warden patrol, you can have them attempt an Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, or Stealth check against the Pitax Wardens’ Reflex DC to see if they can get away, with a failure resulting in a fight. Once an encounter with a Warden patrol finishes, if the PCs don’t use their next Exploration activity to Lie Low, they lose 1d4+2 Liberation Points as a result of increased patrols spreading fear through the populace.

City Walls

Pitax’s stone city walls are strong and sturdy, oft repaired and enhanced—particularly over the past year as Irovetti has had increasing convictions that his city should be more fortified. The walls themselves offer few handholds—it’s a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30|traits:action:climb] check to Climb them—but their primary purpose is to provide numerous points of fortification for a wide range of ballistae, catapults, and other siege engines. The king makes sure to keep these well-attended, ensuring that any attempt to take Pitax by force will pay dearly for the attempt.

B1. The Devil’s Tusks.name: B1. The Devil’s Tusks
B1. The Devil’s Tusks.text:
Pitax makes its home along a tributary of the Sellen River known as the Pitax River, a place known for its treacherous rapids. Here, two small peninsulas jut out from the shore, forming a natural gateway and protective harbor. Those unfamiliar with navigating the narrow strait between the peninsulas—the Devil’s Tusks, known more informally as the Tusks—quickly find their ships stuck on the jagged rocks lurking just beneath the water’s surface. A pair of lighthouses, one on each of the Tusks, serve as beacons to guide ships safely into the harbor, but presently only the southern lighthouse functions as originally intended.

Pursue Opportunity: If the PCs seek out and contact the eastern lighthouse’s attendant Saufie Cintost (CN female human lightkeeper 5), a stocky woman with an endlessly creative penchant for foul-mouthed but good-natured jokes, they can attempt a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:32] check to convince her to aid the rebellion by misleading enemy ships, flashing signals as needed, or observing harbor traffic. On a critical success, she’ll give the PCs two @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.TSrbwHW8zm0mhkwb] to aid them in their fight against Irovetti.

B2. Moondock.name: B2. Moondock
B2. Moondock.text:
Once past the Tusks, ships sailing into Pitax find four smallish wooden docks along the city’s shores. The docks are prominently flanked by warehouses owned by the major Trade Houses.

Only one average-sized ship is allowed to dock at each of the four piers at any given time, which often proves problematic during heavy trading seasons. Savvy merchants with ships headed to Pitax usually provide their captains with handsome bribes to pay the Trade Houses of the city to shorten their wait for docking time.

Pursue Opportunity: Several dockworkers do what they can to help smuggle those in danger out of the city, but their methods and tactics could use some improvement. The PCs can attempt a @Check[type:stealth|dc:32] check to teach the dockworkers a few quick trade secrets on how to smuggle. On a critical success, a dockworker reveals that, less than a month ago, he peeked into a shipment that was to be delivered to Irovetti’s palace and was surprised to see a crate full of clockwork parts and explosives. He later did some research and determined that these parts could be used to craft automatically-firing crossbows or debilitating bombs. Until the PCs came along, the worker hadn’t met anyone he trusted to share this knowledge with. Armed with it, the PCs gain a +4 circumstance bonus on Perception and skill checks made to notice or disarm the clockwork crossbow or flash-bang traps in the palace (see @UUID[.6iBMzJuFC0BGtDHj]).

B3. Riversong Trade House.name: B3. Riversong Trade House
B3. Riversong Trade House.text:
From this large warehouse, the Vascari family controls trade with the ships that come to Pitax. As a result, every sailor in Pitax owes at least a little allegiance to the Vascaris, since if word gets out that the crew of a ship has been disrespectful or treacherous against the Vascaris, that ship can find itself never getting scheduled time for official import, limiting their trade opportunities to illicit markets or smuggling operations.

The Vascaris follow the rule of Jhofre Vascari (LN male human rogue 9). At a young age, Jhofre departed the city; he then spent much of his life as an ordinary merchant captain, establishing contacts along the length of the Sellen River. Despite his lineage, the other Bandit Houses and most citizens view Jhofre as an outsider, so his influence is diminished.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Vascaris using @Check[type:society|dc:32] or @Check[type:mercantile-lore|dc:32].

B4. Iron Fox Armory.name: B4. Iron Fox Armory
B4. Iron Fox Armory.text:
The Liacenzas based their operations in this building for many years, but in the span of just a few weeks, the previous leaders, brothers Lothaire and Berengar, lost control of the Iron Fox Trade House to Irovetti in a series of bizarre incidents culminating in some very unfortunate games of chance. Two short weeks after that, the two brothers disappeared without a trace. Irovetti now uses his newly renamed Iron Fox Armory as a staging ground for the Pitax Wardens’ patrols.

Pursue Opportunity: Traffic through the Iron Fox Armory is constant and brisk, but there are gaps every now and then where the building is mostly empty. During this time, the PCs can Pursue an Opportunity by attempting a trained @Check[type:thievery|dc:32] check to sabotage armor and weapons stored here. On a critical success, the work is so effective that, from this point onward, all Pitax Wardens fought by the PCs during this chapter receive a –1 item penalty to their AC and attack rolls as their gear has been tampered with in ways that they never quite catch on to.

Effect

@UUID[Item.272fqZPLnKt9x2l3]

Apply this effect to the @UUID[Actor.SaSXYUpSWIFHIzET] to impose a -1 penalty to their attack rolls and AC.

B5. The Dwarf’s Cave.name: B5. The Dwarf’s Cave
B5. The Dwarf’s Cave.text:
Near Moondock sits a short, squat building reminiscent of its stout owner, Shipmaster of the Yards Joravin Pyathe (N male dwarven fighter 8). Appointed to his position by the Liacenza brothers during their rule of Pitax, the shipmaster keeps close watch over the goods that make their way between the ships and city, ensuring that merchants coming into the city pay the appropriate tariffs for their goods. Though none of the Bandit Houses particularly like Pyathe, he acts as an arbiter for disputes between the various families, and his gruff but fair disposition means that he never shows favorites. Although Irovetti’s tendency to implement arbitrary adjustments to shipping codes and taxes often makes Joravin an unwelcome sight on the docks, the dwarf proves adept at deflecting ire from himself to the city’s lord.

Pursue Opportunity: The PCs can use a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:32] check to Pursue an Opportunity with Joravin to convince him to increase those “arbitrary adjustments” on anything associated with Irovetti or the Pitax Wardens while relaxing things going to the Bandit Houses slightly. On a critical success, word gets back to the Bandit Houses about the PC’s influence—from this point on, reduce all of the DCs for Gaining Faction Favor by 2.

B6. The Rose Tower.name: B6. The Rose Tower
B6. The Rose Tower.text:
Raids by river pirates caused significant damage to this structure, rendering it inoperable. Seeing no immediate need to repair this lighthouse, the Trade Houses let it lie abandoned for years. In recent times, though, several allied groups of drug dealers and alchemists have taken over its ruins, using the lower levels as a laboratory to concoct their stupefying tinctures.

These are the so-called Dealers of Pitax, and their current leader, Kharne Vareel (NE male gnome rogue 13) sees nothing but opportunity in how the fear of war has frightened the citizens, for during such times, the Dealers’ wares are in even greater demand. Irovetti isn’t interested in disrupting the drug trade flourishing in his city, far preferring it to the active banditry of the past, but he does demand that the Dealers provide him with a share of their profits. Vareel has paid the king’s cut regularly so far, seeing it as something of a “sin tax” that helps the Dealers gain more traction among the desperate of Pitax.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Dealers of Pitax using a @Check[type:intimidation|dc:32] or @Check[type:underworld-lore|dc:32] check.

B7. Tower of the Fallen.name: B7. Tower of the Fallen
B7. Tower of the Fallen.text:
In recent years, with the rebuilding of the New Ruins, the people of Pitax lost much of the land that they once used as a graveyard. For a brief time previous to this, they had buried most of their dead on a small hill just outside the city, but then learned—much to their dismay— that the burials had begun to attract ghouls. With few options apart from inviting more ghoul attacks, clerics of Calistria expanded and converted the basement of one of the largest of the city’s guard towers into a hallowed sepulcher, and since that time, many of the respected dead of Pitax have been laid to rest in the tower’s several new sub-basements in vaults meant to keep things in as well as out.

Pursue Opportunity: The ghouls that infest this area are individually not matches for the PCs, but they are tenacious and numerous. The PCs can Pursue an Opportunity here by attempting a @Check[type:religion|dc:32] check to cull some of the ghouls and create divine wards that prevent them from returning. On a critical success, the churches of Desna and Calistria alike take note. This reduces the DCs to Gain Faction Favor with both religions by 2, and also sees agents from both churches granting the PCs a few scrolls as thanks.

@UUID[Actor.UHkUonjVvoojepdO]: On a critical success, the grateful churches offer the players a scroll of restoration (4th), a scroll of heal (4th), and a scroll of raise dead.

B8. The Temple of Desna.name: B8. The Temple of Desna
B8. The Temple of Desna.text:
Mostly ignored by the sailors coming into port, the Temple of Desna nevertheless has a small but faithful congregation of worshippers. The old but venerable priest Ghare Leotos (CG male human cleric 6) leads the services for these faithful and is responsible for organizing many of the festivities on Desna’s holy days for the city. Since Irovetti took over, the priests here have trodden lightly, taking care not to anger their fickle king. So far, the tactic is working, which has emboldened some of the clergy into slowly expanding their efforts to support and aid those in the city who are oppressed or have fallen on hard times.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Desnans using @Check[type:religion|dc:32] or @Check[type:desna-lore|dc:32].

B9. Serpent’s Breath Trade House.name: B9. Serpent’s Breath Trade House
B9. Serpent’s Breath Trade House.text:
Xapiri Yasmina (LE female human sorcerer 10), a mysterious merchant from Cheliax, recently purchased controlling interest in the Serpent’s Breath Trade House. While the Cattaneis themselves wanted no part of this deal, they were forced to accept it lest they succumb to complete financial ruin. Today, the Trade House functions primarily as a base of operations for Xapiri’s studies into sorcery as she seeks proof of her theory that infernal influences on a person’s blood make them more suited to leadership, and that hellspawn tieflings should be idolized and encouraged rather than vilified as examples of weakness by House Thrune. She has been using the Trade House’s revenue to fund these investigations and experiments, with the needs of the Cattaneis often being set aside, marginalized, or entirely ignored. What Xapiri has told no one is that she didn’t leave Cheliax voluntarily but was forced to flee when House Thrune caught wind of her research.

Though the Cattanei family had the greatest role in founding Pitax, its influence in the city diminished with each passing year. The actions of the traitor Ludov Cattanei a hundred years ago weakened their reputation, and the civil war that followed shortly thereafter nearly destroyed them. The Cattaneis, along with their Serpent’s Breath Trade House, possess just a fraction of the wealth of the other Houses, yet they cling tenaciously to their legacy. Salvarri Cattanei (N male human bard 8) saw the influx of money from Xapiri’s purchase as a chance to rebuild his family’s reputation, but now he’s coming to realize he may have sold more than the Trade House itself.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Cattaneis using @Check[type:society|dc:32] or @Check[type:mercantile-lore|dc:32].

Pursue Opportunity: Xapiri has largely ignored the politics of the region, but after watching or observing her for a time, the PCs might notice that she seems nervous about something. The PCs can Pursue an Opportunity with a Perception check to realize she’s fearful of Chelish agents finding her. A success or critical success at this check doesn’t grant Liberation Points but does allow the PCs to attempt a @Check[type:deception|dc:32] check to convince Xapiri that there are Chelish agents in the region. On a success at this check, she decides to take a lower profile and to lean into the role of a trader, focusing her efforts more on bolstering the Cattanei fortunes for the short term. This grants the PCs 1 Liberation Point and a +2 circumstance bonus on checks to Gain Faction Favor with the Cattaneis. On a critical success at this Deception check, Xapiri instead abandons Pitax entirely, leaving the Trade House fully in control of the Cattaneis. This grants the PCs 2 Liberation Points and either gives them an automatic Critical Success at Gaining Faction Favor with the Cattaneis (if the PCs haven’t attempted this yet) or earns them a reward of 250 pp from the grateful Bandit House (if they have already gained favor).

B10. Darkwind Trade House.name: B10. Darkwind Trade House
B10. Darkwind Trade House.text:
The Darkwind Trade House is run by the Strocalle family and focuses on trade that comes and goes from the city via land routes. While this Trade House continues to do well (particularly during peak trade seasons when river trade is heavily moderated and controlled), the Strocalles have had to spend the majority of the income from these dealings to pay bribes, recruit protection, and otherwise fend off attempts by others who seek to horn in on their business.

No one in Pitax trusts the Strocalles. Their loyalties lie first with profit and second with members of their own house, with all others being a very distant third. Strocalle treachery weaves its way throughout the history of Pitax. Of all the families, the Strocalles maintain the closest ties with the city’s criminal element. Eliste Strocalle (NE human female rogue 8) controls both the Darkwind Wind Trade House and the Strocalle family. Scheming and ambitious, her plotting proved instrumental in Irovetti’s ascent to power. Her family’s alliance with the city’s ruler is stronger than many suspect, and she eventually plans—with Irovetti’s help—to eliminate the other Trade Houses.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Strocalles using @Check[type:society|dc:32] or @Check[type:mercantile-lore|dc:32], but due to their strong alliance with Irovetti, the DCs for checks to Gain Faction Favor with them are increased by 5 unless the PCs have already gained favor with the other three Bandit Houses, in which case peer pressure removes this DC increase.

B11. The Crow’s Feather.name: B11. The Crow’s Feather
B11. The Crow’s Feather.text:
This once sleepy inn doubles as the city’s library, granting access to a hodgepodge collection of books to anyone with the coin to pay for a meal. The mead is watery and the bread is stale, but this matters little to its scholarly patrons. Though the Crow’s Feather remained a little-known oddity to the citizens of Pitax for years, the recent influx of scholars and artists has transformed the small tavern into a bustling meeting place, constantly filled at all hours with would-be academics. A curmudgeonly fellow by the name of Roald Celinnas (LN male human wizard 8) owns the inn. Thought to be the great-grandson of a wizard from Brevoy, Celinnas publicly shows little interest in magic and claims to have found his vast collection of writings “in a box somewhere.” He gladly lets those interested in the collection read through whatever they like, but only so long as they do so in the confines of the Crow’s Feather while ordering from its overpriced menu. Although no part of the collection is for sale, Roald does accept trades—though his measure of what marks a book’s worth is a mystery only he knows the answer to—and he seems to have an uncanny sense of who might be scheming to rob him.

Pursue Opportunity: The PCs can Pursue an Opportunity here by attempting an @Check[type:arcana|dc:32] check to talk shop with Roald while simultaneously working to convince him to aid the PCs’ liberation efforts. On a critical success, he agrees to let the PCs use the back rooms of the Crow’s Feather as a place to hide out, giving the PCs a refuge in town. Additionally, he’ll relate to the PCs that he’s heard rumors that several of Irovetti’s closest allies—and perhaps even his current consort—are monsters capable of changing shape. This information grants the PCs a +2 circumstance bonus to Perception checks when determining the effectiveness of any creature in the palace that uses magic to adopt a disguise.

B12. The Common Square.name: B12. The Common Square
B12. The Common Square.text:
Most residents of the Shattered Ward congregate in the Common Square daily, particularly in the early hours of the morning and at high noon when the bells of Calistria’s cathedral ring loudest. These are the times when the town criers of Pitax appear in the square, announcing the important news of the day and the events of days to come. Merchants and nobles gather in the square to meet and conduct their business, often sitting side by side on the wooden benches circling the giant Fountain of Sorrows, which commemorates those lost in the recent civil war.

The Common Square also draws crowds to its two other prominent features: the stocks and the yardarm (a mast-like structure from which multiple offenders can be hanged and displayed at once). Criminals in Pitax are typically punished with branding, maiming, whipping, or hanging. Irovetti’s Wardens mete out all of these punishments in the square, in full view of all those who choose to bear witness. Many of Pitax’s citizens eagerly turn out to watch, enough so that bread and cheese vendors make handsome profits selling food to the crowds on the days of hangings.

The Common Square has long been the favored place for Annamede Belavarah (CN female human bard 13) to hold court. If the PCs have established a good relationship with her over the course of the adventure—and assuming she survived the hunt in Chapter 5—she’ll notice them here and offer her aid in helping to resist Irovetti. With Annamede’s help, one PC every 3 hours automatically gains a +2 circumstance bonus from Annamede’s assistance on any Liberation activity that relies on a Deception, Diplomacy, Intimidation, Performance, or Society check.

Pursue Opportunity: The PCs can Pursue an Opportunity here to encourage performance-based criticisms of the king and even direct protests with a @Check[type:performance|dc:32] check. On a critical success, word of the scathing performances gets particularly under Irovetti’s skin; as a result, he grows increasingly distracted by these reports and his own efforts to come up with rebuttals—he suffers a –2 penalty on Perception checks for the remainder of this chapter.

B13. Calistria’s Cathedral.name: B13. Calistria’s Cathedral
B13. Calistria’s Cathedral.text:
This cathedral—a building converted from the last remnants of the original keep built by the Cattanei family and the other original settlers of Pitax—is where most of the citizens of Pitax worship. The cathedral’s walls are worn and battered, but those who live in Pitax like it that way. The building stands as a symbol that no matter what happens, Pitax stands above the fray. Lending credence to this is Drey Yarness (CN male human cleric 10), a middle-aged priest and notorious bachelor who watches over the cathedral. Fit and possessing a sharp tongue, Yarness knows much about the city and what goes on within its walls; some say he knows far more than a simple clergyman has any right. As one of Irovetti’s sharpest critics, Drey has drawn a fair number of admirers to his church—people who seek leadership from someone other than their current king more than those who are particularly interested in worshipping Calistria. For now, Irovetti’s fear of potentially angering the goddess of revenge has kept him from publicly reacting to Drey’s attitudes, but it’s growing more and more difficult for the king to resist his urge to send his Wardens into the cathedral in an attempt to have its high priest replaced.

Gain Faction Favor: The PCs can attempt to Gain Faction Favor with the Calistrians using @Check[type:religion|dc:32] or @Check[type:calistria-lore|dc:32].

B14. The Turning Wheel.name: B14. The Turning Wheel
B14. The Turning Wheel.text:
On windy days, the sharp smell of cheese fills the air of east Pitax. This odor emanates from a small, broken tower known as the Turning Wheel, a butcher and cheese shop famed for its foodstuffs. The Wheel serves all of Pitax from its lowliest sailors to its richest merchants, and it’s one of the city’s more popular attractions. Ingras Quill (CG female human cheesemaker 5), its ever-cheerful, middle-aged proprietress, greets all who visit the Wheel, and her ribald jokes attract as many patrons as the food itself. Her weekly shipments to the palace to deliver fresh wares to Irovetti have afforded her a fair amount of goodwill from the king, but what few (particularly Irovetti himself) ever see, however, is Ingras’s loathing for the Pitax Wardens, who callously slaughtered her son for some arbitrary affront a few years ago. Ever since then, a secret room in the Turning Wheel’s basement has served as a meeting place and safe house for any who would bring harm to the city’s ruler or have need to keep watch on the palace nearby.

Pursue Opportunity: The PCs can Pursue an Opportunity here to encourage Ingras to step up her efforts to provide shelter to people persecuted by the Wardens by attempting a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:32] check. On a critical success, the PCs can use the Turning Wheel as a refuge, and Ingras shares with them one of her closest guarded secrets—a journal in which she’s kept exacting notes on guard patrols (including her suspicions of likely places for secret doors that grant the guard patrols shortcuts) in the palace. This information grants the PCs a +2 item bonus on initiative checks made against Pitax Wardens in the palace and to Perception checks to notice secret doors there.

B15. The Palace.name: B15. The Palace
B15. The Palace.text: Once the sprawling manse of an eccentric wizard, this estate—known simply as “the palace”—presently serves as home and headquarters to Irovetti and his loyal followers. Like most things accomplished by Irovetti in Pitax, the bandit king’s acquisition of the palace was both swift and sudden. Full details of Irovetti’s stronghold can be found in @UUID[.e91QGicfFqIvHTho].

B16. Faces of Stone.name: B16. Faces of Stone
B16. Faces of Stone.text:
Amid all of the artistic abominations to be found in Pitax, one shop, Faces of Stone, stands out as a ray of light and hope. The shop is run by sculptor Cayid Caconna (CN male human artisan 10), whose stone works—largely made from the limestone ruins of the fallen walls of Pitax—are genuinely exquisite, and nobles and merchants throughout the River Kingdoms commission work from him. He is responsible for the best of the gargoyle statues spreading across Pitax’s rooftops, and even the awful, tasteless works commissioned by Irovetti still manage to retain vestiges of beauty and dignity. Cayid works mostly at night and never takes on apprentices; in fact, few have ever seen him at work. Most believe this is to guard the dark secret behind his remarkable knack for making stone appear almost alive—local tales tell of Cayid magically turning his artistic rivals into stone. Cayid himself humorously encourages such tales of foul magic and murder, as they flatter what is in actuality pure talent.
