A character who falls plummets 100 feet and lands on the next lower island at its lowest-numbered encounter area, regardless of where the fall began, and even if that area is inside of a structure. A character who falls from the Market instead falls 200 feet before landing at area A1.

Creatures: Just as the Lantern Kingdom’s geography is based on the PCs’ capital, some of its “citizens” are warped duplicates of NPCs from home—some appearing as old enemies, and some as friends. For the latter, choose living NPCs who have leadership roles in the PCs’ kingdom or other trusted allies, excluding any who have accompanied the PCs into the Lantern Kingdom. If you’re using the Kingmaker Companion Guide, any of the companions in that book who remained behind on the Material Plane make great choices.

Resting: The Lantern King allows the PCs to rest on any one island once, out of “fairness” to keep the entertainment going. If the PCs attempt to rest on the same island more than once, they’ll be attacked at some point during the rest by a group of four @UUID[Actor.fQ9FuovHuRt6vtcq] (a Moderate 20 encounter) who haughtily warn the PCs to not dawdle—to “keep moving or suffer.” If the PCs refuse, they must defeat the wild hunt, after which they earn the chance for the additional rest. Each additional rest on that island adds one wild hunt scout to the resulting encounter, to a maximum of a dozen scouts (an Extreme 20 encounter). There are enough constantly blooming fruits and berries among the foliage overgrowing the shattered city, along with small pools of water here and there that refill magically over time, so that PCs who are trapped for many days in the Lantern Kingdom can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.49y9Ec4bDii8pcD3] with a @Check[type:survival|dc:35|traits:action:subsist] check. A character who rolls a critical failure while attempting to Subsist attracts trouble in the form of a group of four Wild Hunt scouts, as detailed above.

The Market.name: The Market
The Market.text: The lowest island grouping appears to have been ripped from the mercantile heart of the PCs’ capital. Use the Market map for encounters that take place here, but feel free to alter the shape of the region or the names of buildings found therein to match locations that are more familiar to the PCs from their own capital.

A1. A Familiar Place.name: A1. A Familiar Place
A1. A Familiar Place.text:
When the PCs arrive in the Lantern Kingdom, they do so here. As you present the readaloud text below, you should adjust it as needed to make it apparent that the shop into which they appear is one that they frequent in their capital—if not a place the PCs helped to build, then certainly one that they often visit.

This ruined shop instills a vague sense of deja-vu, while the vista looking out from a mostly collapsed wall is entirely new: a gulf of swirling clouds in which fragments of a familiar city float on rocky islets overgrown with a tangle of alien plant life. Some of these isles are only a few feet across, connected to others by tangles of vines, while one much larger island looms in the sky a hundred feet above in the other direction. Here, glimpses of a ruined, overgrown city are visible, as is a rising “bridge” of thorny vines that winds up from this island grouping to the one above. In the distance, what appear to be vast shimmering fields of glass look out over a void of scintillating light in which drift glimpses of a vast, drifting, burning sphere surrounded by clouds of runes—a sphere that gives you the unmistakable sensation that it is watching.

Add as many other elements as you wish to make it apparent to the PCs that they have appeared not only in a familiar, but ruined store, but within the shattered remains of their own capital. No recognizable NPCs, living or dead, are apparent, and the longer the PCs remain in this realm, the more they should notice strange errors or inconsistencies with what should otherwise be familiar places, as if this shattered city were a duplicate created by someone not wholly familiar with the source. Strange spellings for street names, slightly different images on building signs, and fragmentary statues depicting villains the PCs have previously clashed with are great examples of such off-kilter elements.

Success on a @Check[type:nature|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:religion|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check identifies the “vast burning sphere” that seems to be observing the PCs as the Lantern King himself.

A2. Familiar Faces?.name: A2. Familiar Faces?
A2. Familiar Faces?.text:
As the PCs step out of the ruined shop at area A1, describe to them another familiar (but ruined) building here that represents another shop they frequent that, in their actual capital, but is not normally located next door to the first. This should help the PCs (and thus the players) recognize they’re in a warped reality rather than in their actual capital after some sort of unknown apocalypse destroyed it.

@UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]

Moderate 20

This building is currently occupied by four fetch stalkers created in the images of people the PCs have allied with. They emerge from this shop soon after the PCs arrive in the Lantern Kingdom in area @UUID[.bUY4YHhEtaHpQHOX], loudly calling out the PCs’ names and daring them to “step out into the open to face their failures.”

These fetches accuse the PCs of leaving them behind while their kingdom fell, and demand retribution in the form of execution. A PC can see through the fetches’ claims that they’re actual survivors from the PCs’ fallen kingdom as normal, but even if the fetch stalkers successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ewwCglB7XOPLUz72] to the entire party, it’s likely that the PCs won’t trust these figures. The fetches don’t waste too much time arguing, and attack soon after they find the PCs.

Journal

@UUID[.GdLTXf0fVKacfMKG]

The linked journal page contains additional information on Fetches, as well as some custom effects that can be used to quickly change the tokens of the creatures that your players will encounter within the Lantern Kingdom.

A3. Strange Tavern.name: A3. Strange Tavern
A3. Strange Tavern.text:
This small building appears to be in better condition than the others in the Market. The building itself should be based on a tavern from the PCs’ capital, although strangely reduced in size so as to accommodate only the main room. Doors or halls that, in the real world, lead to other parts of the tavern should simply provide alternate exits and entrances to this main chamber.

@UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]

Low 19

Only one being occupies this tavern—one of the Lantern King’s loyal agents, the gimmerling Werendegar. Among other things, Werendegar (who introduces himself simply by the name “Weren”) has been responsible for moving Briar to new hiding places each time Nyrissa absorbs a kingdom and moves on to a new world. Now that this task is no longer needed due to the PCs’ actions, the Lantern King has given Werendegar a new job: welcoming the PCs to the Lantern Kingdom. The gimmerling does his best to hide his frustration at this “babysitting” task.

As soon as the PCs defeat the fetches at area @UUID[.0XhNnb1JktH9BMlX], Werendegar makes himself known by stepping out of the tavern where he has been relaxing. He appears to the PCs in his true form, that of a handsome but clawed and sharp-toothed half-elven man. He greets the PCs by name, then welcomes them to the Lantern Kingdom and notes that they may have questions—and he’s eager to give them answers.

Werendegar’s purpose here is to encourage the PCs to make their way to the @UUID[.BX7f7hUaiYuBNSjn] to present their case to the Lantern King himself—should they be allowed to live and return home? Werendegar further explains to the PCs that in order to earn this audience with the Lantern King, they must first provide him entertainment in the form of their struggles to reach him. They must prove themselves as “true adventurers worth his time” by navigating their shattered city and triumphing over enemies they thought defeated (this is a reference to several fetches that present to the PCs in familiar forms). He also informs the PCs that when they “broke the Apology” (if needed, he’ll clarify that he’s talking about the chalice that was shattered in the @UUID[.L8UvMkhoqamn3kBj]), they insulted the Lantern King. He tells the PCs that the Apology was offered to Nyrissa out of the “Lantern King’s inestimable mercy,” and that if the PCs wish to leave the Lantern Kingdom, they must rebuild the Apology by recovering its three shards, which have been scattered throughout “your broken home” (he indicates the shattered capital all around him at this point).

Once the PCs have all three shards of the Apology and make their way to the throne room, Werendegar promises that the Lantern King will make time to hear their pleas for mercy. He provides honest answers for any questions the PCs have about the nature of the Lantern Kingdom. Questions about the Lantern King or himself, though, Werendegar answers more obliquely, implying that the PCs should save those questions for the Lantern King. He won’t offer any other unsolicited advice.

Once Werendegar grows bored or annoyed with the PCs, or as soon as he has been attacked, he smirks and says, “see you soon!” before he flees—using @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wfleiawxsfhpRRwf] and/or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8] to retreat to area @UUID[.yzcTP7RoOiPK5dOT] to await the PCs there.

A4. The Roof Bridge.name: A4. The Roof Bridge
A4. The Roof Bridge.text:
A gap between two overgrown islands has been bridged here by a building that has partially collapsed into the void. Only the upper walls and wood-shingled roof of the building remains, forming a sort of bridge between the two islands. The steeply angled roofline makes crossing it a daunting task, even if one were to attempt to do so along the narrow roof beam across its center.

The roof bridge is stable, and can support any amount of weight, but it still remains a tricky way to move from the southern islands of the Market to the northern one. As anyone attempts to cross this “bridge,” loose shingles slip, slippery patches of standing water or runny mold well up from the wood, and tiny vines growing on the building twist and grasp with lives of their own at those who cross. As a result of these conditions, a character can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy] across the sloped roofs with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:climb] check or walk along the narrow beam by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej] with a @Check[type:acrobatics|dc:40|traits:action:balance] check. A critical failure results in a fall, after which the character lands on the ground on the original side of the bridge they started from.

  • @UUID[Actor.tjq87ghubOcPAXjj]
  • @UUID[Item.qVChn1FaOqDx7JFf]

Hargulka's Fetch

Trivial 20

The roof bridge is the lesser danger facing the PCs here, for a potentially familiar face lurks among the foliage just north of the roof. This is a lumbering fetch behemoth who wears the guise of the troll king Hargulka. He waits until the PCs are split between the two islands, preferably when at least one PC is still navigating the roof bridge, before he emerges from the trees with a roar to attack. He rolls Stealth for initiative, and his bellowing challenge alerts the vilderavns in area @UUID[.UI216yii0AFAECti] who join the battle at the start of the 3rd round (increasing this from a Trivial 20 encounter to a Severe 20 one).

A5. Fragmented Inn.name: A5. Fragmented Inn
A5. Fragmented Inn.text:
This building is similar to the one at area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch], save that it appears as an inn the PCs frequented or built in their capital; inside, all that exists is the inn’s foyer, with other doors that once provided access to additional rooms now simply providing exits or entrances to the inn itself.

@UUID[Actor.UXXEOnvp2MDaS9Sc]

Moderate 20

The Lantern King is served by many fey, but he particularly favors vilderavn heralds as his agents in the Stolen Lands—the PCs may have encountered one of them before as a random encounter in Thousand Voices. The three heralds posted here in this fragmented inn, though, are instead failures who are serving out penance as guards. The Lantern King has ordered them to slay the PCs if they attempt to reach this part of the Market, and he has promised all three heralds that they’ll be allowed to return to their duties elsewhere if they succeed. As such, the vilderavns are eager to earn their freedom, and they fight to the death as soon as they notice the PCs (likely as a result of hearing a roar from the fetch behemoth at area @UUID[.ocC3GJNcUQrLCTdO]).

A6. Crumbling Workshop.name: A6. Crumbling Workshop
A6. Crumbling Workshop.text:
This large, roofless structure should be described to the PCs to remind them of a guildhall, library, laboratory, or other workshop that they built in their kingdom. It’d be best if the workshop itself was based on one in which one of the PCs spent time crafting magic items or otherwise @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QyzlsLrqM0EEwd7j] over the course of the campaign to this point. Within, the roof is missing, but the PCs should find a fair amount of supplies and items that could be used as resources—see Treasure below.

  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]
  • @UUID[Item.wFjP2DzJGRhex3rI]
  • @UUID[Actor.vONZlReozVCabXhq]

Encounter

Trivial 20

While the Lantern King delights in testing the PCs’ ability as they make their way up to his throne room, he also likes to think of himself as not being unfair—as someone who plays by the rules (even if the “rules” in this case are a collection of often self-contradicting whims). Setting up Werendegar as a “greeter” in area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch] is one such concession to “playing fair,” and Gribbler, a fetch stalker who takes the form of a redcap rather than of an NPC known by the PCs, is another.

Gribbler’s task is to welcome the PCs to the workshop, to inform them that he’s here to provide what aid he can, and to show them that the workshop’s contents are theirs to draw upon as they see fit. Gribbler explains that the PCs are free to spend as long as they wish here—but only as long as it takes for each of them to finish a single task.

At your option, if the PCs attempt to game this system, Gribbler might grow impatient and attack. He does his best to be honest and friendly, and he’ll even warn the PCs about the unstable flooring to the west if he thinks that aid will help earn the PCs’ trust. Gribbler is true to his word in helping them with any tasks they perform here—he’ll use the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW] reaction as you see fit—but that doesn’t mean he’s entirely forthright.

The Lantern King has a constant telepathic link with Gribbler, and anything and everything the PCs say or do in his presence is immediately reported via this link. Gribbler tries to cover this up and becomes evasive if asked about his relationship with the Lantern King; if pressed on it, he shrieks in frustration and attacks rather than risk giving up the truth that he has been spying on the PCs.

Hazard: While the westernmost section of this building appears to be solid, if anyone walks on the floor there, it will collapse and fall away.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.fSVpkIa3fyDYXLCg]

Plays the sound of splintering wood as the floor collapses, then exposes the broken floorboards and the fall beneath after a brief pause. Run the macro again to restore the floor to its original state.

Treasure: This workshop can provide the PCs with supplies to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.24PSsn1SKpUwYA1X], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.rmwa3OyhTZ2i2AHl] magic items, or pursue one Downtime activity each while trapped in the Lantern Kingdom. The supplies found here are worth 75,000 gp in all; any items or retraining the PCs pursue uses this pool of gp, and once it’s depleted, the workshop can no longer be used in this fashion. It’s possible to transport these resources out of the Lantern Kingdom, but they’re so bulky that it should take dozens of trips.

A7. Ascending Vines.name: A7. Ascending Vines
A7. Ascending Vines.text:
A thick tangle of vines rises upward at a steep angle to attach to a floating block of earth and stone a hundred feet overhead, ending at what appears to be an open doorway in the side of a stone building. Now and then, the vines seem to shiver or twist on their own, and flowers bloom and wilt at an unnerving pace along the length, as if time itself were an untrustworthy constant.

Despite their appearance, these vines can be ascended fairly easily by high-level characters—it’s only a @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|traits:action:climb] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy] them. Characters who do so find themselves entering the @UUID[.Riwc58VZoiQZg1ZG] at area @UUID[.V3YlfDlUeyi85SRr].

The Residence.name: The Residence
The Residence.text:
The second island area the PCs visit in their journey through the Lantern Kingdom is a modest, one-bedroom home referred to here as the Residence. This building should be based, if possible, on homes connected with the PCs—be it their current domiciles, homes they grew up in, or the like. Descriptions of rooms below (including the map of the area provided here) are bare-bones as a result; you should add in a few extra bits of flavor to each to drive home the fact that this structure is eerily familiar to each of them in different ways. The idea that one of their greatest enemies, King Irovetti, has “moved into their home” should not be lost on the PCs.

The Residence has one entrance (into area @UUID[.V3YlfDlUeyi85SRr]) but several exits that each reveal another overgrown island of ruined buildings; characters who emerge from the Residence through any of these step out into area @UUID[.nUE3P7NYaSoVmjqb].

B1. Storeroom.name: B1. Storeroom
B1. Storeroom.text:
Shelves along the walls of this storeroom are filled with all matter of strange, eclectic objects, all caked with a thick layer of dust. A door stands in both the east and west wall; to the north, a partially collapsed wall looms over the strange vista of this weird realm above a cascading tangle of vines that leads downward.

Each PC enters this room from the door to the west and immediately experiences a strange sense of déjà vu: the room feels familiar in a way that evokes their own childhood home. For one PC it might be the scent of a parent’s cooking lingering in the air. For another it might be a familiar carving they left on a beam as a child. For a third it could be the way they accidentally bump their head on an annoying overhanging beam, just like they’d done countless times before as they entered the room through the doorway. Any PC who looks through the shelves immediately recognizes several objects from their home, many of which they may have thought were lost forever. These objects are mundane in nature, and a closer examination along with success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40] check is enough to note strange disconnects between the object and memory, as if the item were reconstructed by someone operating from a detailed description but who never actually saw the original.

B2. Main Hall.name: B2. Main Hall
B2. Main Hall.text:
A dining table is the focal point in this large, open hall, sitting against the middle of the southern wall and surrounded by a half-dozen comfortable-looking wooden chairs. Doors are present in every direction but north, where an archway allows passage into the bedroom beyond. Shelves and display cabinets sit against the northern wall to either side of the archway.

Elements in this room should evoke memories of living rooms and common areas in the PCs’ homes.

The eastern double door provides an exit from the @UUID[.Riwc58VZoiQZg1ZG] into the @UUID[.lJaJrbm2pkgjuON1] isle.

  • @UUID[Actor.8eTfnYg0xmcgmDVQ]
  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]

Encounter

Severe 20

A “family” of four fetch stalkers dwells here. Each should resemble a family member of a different PC—perhaps a parent, a sibling, a cousin, or in the case of a PC who never knew their family, a friend or other NPC they’ve grown close to. The fetch stalkers welcome the PCs with a strange sense of delight and cheer, acting as if all of them being together in this strange manner isn’t unusual at all. The fetch stalkers seek to have the PCs seated at the table, saying “dinner is about to be served” as they bustle about.

If the PCs comply, the fetches serve them fine food and drink, and you can play out this strange dinner party as long as you wish with the false family members giving nonsensical answers to the PCs when asked. Unless the PCs attack the fetches (in which case the fey shriek words like “betrayers” and “traitors” as they procure long fetch knives to fight back), their fetch family eventually reveals to them that the “master of the house” is joining them presently. A moment later, Castruccio Irovetti’s fetch emerges from the private quarters (area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t]) to attack, accusing the PCs of “stealing his home” and rolling Intimidation for his initiative. (If the PCs instigated the fight on their own, Irovetti’s fetch joins the fight on the second round and rolls initiative using Perception instead.)

Irovetti’s fetch manifests as a larger-than-life version of his previous incarnation—a towering, overly muscular creature nearly fourteen feet tall, dressed in rags and adorned with a crown that seems to grow from his skull rather than simply worn atop his head. His fetch weapon appears identical to a flaming version of his rod of razors, but it functions only as a fetch weapon, not the technological item he wielded in life.

B3. Kitchen.name: B3. Kitchen
B3. Kitchen.text:
This fair-sized kitchen and pantry has a large stone washbasin next to a rain barrel, fed from a pipe coming out of the wall. The south wall has a large stone cooking hearth; ashen logs and soot spill from the opening and across the floor. Next to the fireplace rests a stack of neatly chopped firewood. Hooks on the walls hold an assortment of pots, spoons, ladles and other cookware.

The double door to the west provides an exit from the Residence, as do the ones to the east and south.

Treasure: When the Lantern King drew upon dreams and memories harvested from the PCs and their legacy, not everything became weaponized against them—there were some unanticipated side effects, such as those found in this room.

Any PC who enters the kitchen experiences a feeling of protection and safety, be it in the form of warm memories of loving parents, the support of a deity, or simply recollections of old friendships. These feelings automatically draw each PC to an item of food or drink in the kitchen they instinctively recognize as a cherished meal from childhood. Whatever the form of this meal, the PC also understands immediately upon touching the meal that it functions as an @UUID[Actor.k3H5Gr286nd7pXkF.Item.GySfs5UwiADSIFTG].

B4. Private Quarters.name: B4. Private Quarters
B4. Private Quarters.text:
This room appears to have been the bedchamber of someone who, while once rich, has fallen on hard times. A rickety bed covered with ratty, once regal sheets extends from the far wall. A chest sits at the foot of the bed, the padlock hanging open from its latch tantalizingly, while a nightstand, an ornately carved but dilapidated wardrobe, and an elegantly shaped but wobbly wooden chair sit to the sides. The room exudes a sense of forlorn nostalgia, as if memory itself is trapped here.

As the PCs look through this bedroom, they should recognize a few things from their home (be it current or childhood), but these objects have been broken, vandalized, or otherwise ruined by Irovetti’s Fetch. The PCs encounter him here if they somehow manage to avoid attracting his attention in area @UUID[.NrwIOizVhZGB2DUu]. The door to the west provides an exit from the Residence.

@UUID[Actor.iqMMrq96o3c6D0vs]: The chest at the foot of the bed is unlocked, and within is a large misshapen object fashioned from metal and glass, radiating a pale golden glow. This is one of the three shards of the Apology: the chalice stem. The shard is Bulk 1, and if the PCs learned of the shards from Werendegar, they automatically recognize it for what it is. Otherwise, success on a DC 40 check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.eReSHVEPCsdkSL4G] reveals the truth.

The Nobles.name: The Nobles
The Nobles.text:
Reaching the Nobles island is a simple matter of exiting the Residence through any of its doors or windows. When the PCs do so, they emerge from area @UUID[.nUE3P7NYaSoVmjqb].

This island is based on whichever part of the PCs’ capital is inhabited by the most nobles and aristocrats. The open area between the ruined manors to the north and south is strewn with bodies and bears obvious signs of recent combat. The bodies resemble allies, friends, and recognizable citizens from the PCs’ capital, but they’re little more than decoration; success at a @Check[type:nature|dc:35] check confirms that the “corpses” are in fact cleverly cultivated plants that have been grown into shapes resembling bodies.

The Lantern King set this area up to create a mock clash between an ally and an enemy of the PCs: Lady Jamandi and Vordakai. In fact, both are fetches who seek to toy with the PCs before killing them off.

C1. Dilapidated Home.name: C1. Dilapidated Home
C1. Dilapidated Home.text:
Regardless of the method the PCs use to exit the Residence, they do so as if stepping through a partially ruined doorframe on the west face of what appears to be a partially collapsed house. Even a cursory inspection of this house reveals that it seems to be a ruined version of a childhood home, appearing differently to each viewer. A character who enters this house at any point finds themselves returning to area @UUID[.NrwIOizVhZGB2DUu] in the Residence.

Unless the PCs take pains to remain stealthy when they arrive, they’ll be spotted by “allies” to the north who quickly call out their names and wave them over toward areas @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci] and @UUID[.OUC9y0vcIOsbhHE8].

C2. Collapsed Outbuilding.name: C2. Collapsed Outbuilding
C2. Collapsed Outbuilding.text:
This collapsed building looks to have once been a groundskeeper’s cottage, but little remains today save for crumbled timbers.

@UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]

Low 20

Three fetch stalkers hunker down here, apparently watching to the south for any advance from their “enemies” in areas @UUID[.YkyTUz4HPWkDnHOu] and @UUID[.FebpS0rXrOExrYgC]. In fact, they’re waiting to call out to the PCs. These three fetches should appear as friendly NPCs the PCs know from the Stolen Lands—good choices for identities might include @UUID[Item.TT1TNtcCeSrszBzn] and @UUID[Item.MMYQCpBHAXK5ca34] Leveton, or even @UUID[Item.E5IODdO3DoibqoaD] or another now deceased ally, but feel free to swap these out for other NPCs the PCs have grown close to.

The three fetches appear grateful but worried as they approach the PCs. Unless they’re immediately attacked, they explain that they’ve been drawn into this strange world and pitted against none other than Vordakai, back from the dead. The fetches claim to have been clashing with his forces for days, and only a few friendly survivors remain holed up in the nearby manor. The fetches attempt to lead the PCs to area @UUID[.OUC9y0vcIOsbhHE8] to meet their commander, but if the PCs instead attack, those stationed in area C3 come here to join the fight [[/gmroll 1d4]] rounds after combat begins.

C3. Ruined Manor.name: C3. Ruined Manor
C3. Ruined Manor.text:
Only the facade and part of the entry hall of this once-great manor remains standing, the rest of it appearing to have collapsed into the void below.

Add a few additional bits of description to this ruined manor so that the PCs recognize it as Lady Jamandi’s manor house; the fact that it’s incongruously located in what pretends to be the PCs’ capital is yet another awkward element of the Lantern Kingdom’s imperfect attempt to mimic a postapocalyptic Stolen Lands kingdom.

  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]
  • @UUID[Item.Z5wiAJg02Ro5aMOu]
  • @UUID[Item.5sPd7acTmz46i4t2]
  • @UUID[Actor.rkKNyFohD800rxiU]

Encounter

Trivial 20

Another two fetch stalkers wait here, having staged a scene they hope will help the PCs waste some of their resources. The two fetches appear to be friendly NPCs—if you’re using the Kingmaker Companion Guide, choose some from that book who haven’t accompanied the PCs; otherwise, these two fetches should appear to be Ioseph Sellemius and Ivenzi, whom the PCs met in Lady Jamandi’s manor at the start of this campaign.

The two fetches appear to be attending a third figure—a very badly wounded Lady Jamandi, who lies beaten and bloodied on a table. The fetches beg the PCs for aid in healing her. In truth, “Lady Jamandi” is an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.f8SBoXiXQjlCKqly] cast by one of the two fetches. They hope to trick the PCs into depleting some of their healing reserves on Lady Jamandi, who “wakes” from the healing after a few rounds. If the PCs don’t see through the ruse, the illusory Jamandi urges them to accompany her and her remaining allies south to strike at Vordakai, whom she claims “just recently had to retreat after our last fight—we should strike at him before he recovers!”

If the PCs fall for the ruse, the fetch stalkers from here and area @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci] lead the PCs south to area @UUID[.YkyTUz4HPWkDnHOu], and once a fight begins there, they aid the PCs for a few rounds before turning on them and siding with the “enemy.” In any event, the fetch stalkers are quick to switch to combat as soon as they suspect the PCs have seen through their ruse.

Actor

@UUID[Actor.rkKNyFohD800rxiU]

We've included a fake "hazard" that has the appearance of Lady Jamandi, so that you can use it to represent the illusory creature on the map. You may also find it useful for rolling the illusion's damage. Remember to check the text of the Illusory Creature spell if you aren't sure what the illusion is capable of!

Effect

Reflected Soul - @UUID[Item.fXeZQCEmraVYTn7M]

By default, the illusory creature token uses Lady Jamandi's ordinary artwork. If you'd like her to match the fetch appearance of Ioseph and Ivenzi in this encounter, you can use the same effects that we've been applying to the Fetch Stalkers thus far to set the illusion's appearance to a Fetch version of the character!

C4. Sundered Stables.name: C4. Sundered Stables
C4. Sundered Stables.text:
A sprawling wooden stable sits at the edge of this overgrown island, but its once fine features have been sullied with blood, mud, and filth. The roof remains mostly intact, but here and there portions have fallen away into rubble within.

@UUID[Actor.hLBHFloWuXLjCQYH]

Low 20

While these stables may have been used to house prize horses in the Material Plane version of the building, here it houses two immense monstrosities—primal bandersnatches. These massive, six-legged, catlike creatures hide amid the rubble and beams near the building’s roof. As soon as the PCs approach within 15 feet of the building, the two emerge to attack, rolling Stealth for initiative. The sound of their eerie roars is certainly enough to draw “Vordakai” from area @UUID[.FebpS0rXrOExrYgC], who joins the fight at the start of the second round.

C5. Destroyed Mansion.name: C5. Destroyed Mansion
C5. Destroyed Mansion.text:
Only a fragment of one wing survives of what may have once been a glorious, sprawling mansion. Its southwestern face slumps in rubble over the void, while the facade that remains is riddled with holes and splattered with gore.

Feel free to add additional elements to the above description to make the PCs recognize this ruined mansion as a location close to them, be it the sprawling manor of an NPC ally or one of their own residences found within their capital.

  • @UUID[Actor.6zWcjvPya0wWDZv2]
  • @UUID[Item.34iTVVQtmrLdBFhf]

Vordakai's Fetch

Moderate 20

A single deadly occupant lies in wait in this destroyed mansion: a risen fetch based on the cyclops wizard Vordakai. As with all risen fetches, this creature appears as Vordakai did in life, not as he did in undeath—his eye remains intact and his body is hearty and healthy in appearance, yet the PCs should be able to recognize him with ease. Unlike most of the other fetches encountered in the Lantern Kingdom, Vordakai’s fetch has no agenda of trickery; he waits here patiently, hoping the fetches to the east will successfully lead the PCs toward him so that a glorious betrayal will occur. If the PCs instead confront him first, he does his best to use flashy, impossible-to-ignore spell effects and works his way east to draw in the fetches from areas @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci] and @UUID[.OUC9y0vcIOsbhHE8].

Treasure: Vordakai’s fetch carries a shard of the Apology in a pocket of his robes; when he’s slain and his remains decay away, this fractured portion of the @UUID[Item.ilzaIlAlHGZ80a1u] remains behind. As with the previous shard, this shard is Bulk 1; it can be recognized in the same way as the shard in area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t].

C6. The Rising Rock.name: C6. The Rising Rock
C6. The Rising Rock.text:
Macro

@UUID[Macro.OpbX4f9Z41S76GOd]

If your players somehow reach this area while the Rising Rock is in area @UUID[.ub0Oad5bx6zIg5vc] (for instance, by falling from the Park above), you can use this macro to show or hide the floating island in area C6.

A smaller slab of rock, its surface overgrown with plants, visibly bobs in the air here, tethered to the larger, more stable island to the west via a thick tangle of vines. Now and then, the vines twitch and move, as if they were enjoying the act of clutching this rock, or perhaps straining to keep it in place

This smaller isle can be used to ascend 100 feet to the @UUID[.2mRG6whqxVYaKdTx] above. To do so, the vines anchoring it to the Nobles must be destroyed. The vines themselves are numerous but individually easy to break. A minute or so of work is all that’s needed, after which point this islet rises up to the area indicated on the map by the dotted outline adjacent to area @UUID[.ub0Oad5bx6zIg5vc]. The islet remains for 1 minute before it sinks back down to this location and the vines reattach it to the Nobles.

The Park.name: The Park
The Park.text: This island features only two buildings; most of its expanse is a riotous tangle of wildflowers, trees, brambles, fungi, and the like. If the PCs had a park or similar area in their capital, adjust descriptions here and there to make it apparent this region is based on their park. Alternately, if one of the PCs has particularly fond memories of a wilderness location in the Stolen Lands, features from that location might have been pulled in to this tangle as well. Feel free to adjust the overall size and shape of this island if you need more room to integrate a wilderness location like this, or even to attach a map of such an area, such as the Temple of the Elk, to the region.

D1. Snickersnack.name: D1. Snickersnack
D1. Snickersnack.text:
Macro

@UUID[Macro.EP51gGlcBcTJ737u]

When the Rising Rock sinks back to area @UUID[.DiTR9EpCS1SiF1d5], you can use this macro to show or hide the floating island on this scene.

Here, the sprawling tangle of rampant overgrowth rules completely. No sign of civilization is apparent on this isle save for a looming monument glimpsed through trees to the north and brief glimpses of some sort of structure through the overgrowth to the east.

The significant overgrowth on this island outside of the two ruined buildings functions as greater difficult terrain. Worse, the edges of this island consist of mats of deceptive vegetation that hang out over the gulf below. A character who enters any space shared by the island’s edge must make a successful @Check[type:reflex|dc:35] save upon entering that space or plunge through the vegetation into a fall, landing a moment later in the space they left before stepping into nothingness.

@UUID[Actor.Y0qsrBFTFMbaiLzr]

Severe 20

The most dangerous foe the PCs face in the Park is a jabberwock. The immense Tane stomps and burbles and patrols this entire region; it immediately attacks the PCs as soon as it notices them. As the jabberwock moves, the surrounding vegetation parts for its approach as if fearful of its arrival; as such, the jabberwock ignores the greater difficult terrain caused by this island.

@UUID[Actor.19X82z6eIY0QLZrW]: As soon as the PCs slay the jabberwock, it thrashes and crashes as it expires, coughing up a pulsing mass of tissue as it does so; if the jabberwock was defeated via an effect like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.r7ihOgKv19eJQnik] or banished to another plane, the mass of tissue drops to the ground in one of the squares the Tane occupied before it was defeated. The tissue rots away quickly, revealing a few notable treasures in its passing—a third eye and an orichalcum scroll tube (itself worth 2,500 gp) that contains a single scroll (this scroll contains one of the following 10th-level spells, chosen from a tradition that at least one PC can cast: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.h8zxY9hTeHtWsBVW], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.YfJTXyVGzLhM6V8U], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.MLNeD5sAunV0E23j], or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]).

D2. Monument.name: D2. Monument
D2. Monument.text:
A towering but badly eroded monument stands atop a rectangular base here, towering above the surrounding trees. Just beyond the monument to the north, a stump of land extends toward the region’s highest island floating above. Atop this last island stands a familiar-looking structure.

Adjust the monument’s description to match the largest or most notable monument in the PCs’ kingdom—if none exist, it is instead a monument to the kingdom’s ruler. The “familiar-looking structure” on the upper island is recognizable as the PCs’ capital building, be it a castle, a palace, or whatever, save that it seems to be in a crumbling state of disrepair with tangles of ivy growing along its walls.

@UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]

Low 20

Unless the PCs defeated him earlier, Werendegar retreats to this location after speaking to them in area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]. He waits patiently, seated atop the monument’s stone base, biding his time with a drink and a book (success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:25] check reveals that the book is Zuddiger’s Picnic). Once Werendegar spots the PCs, he tosses the drink and book aside—they promptly vanish in puffs of smoke—and he calls out to the characters asking if they’ve gathered up the Apology. If not, he shakes his head in disappointment and waves them off to finish the task.

If they’ve gathered all three shards, he claps in delight and hops down from the monument, beckoning for the PCs to follow him north to area @UUID[.8Y896ivCvpkJrJFI]. If the PCs attack him, he flees via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8] to the Palace’s throne room, leaving the PCs to find their own way forward.

D3. The House Beyond Time.name: D3. The House Beyond Time
D3. The House Beyond Time.text:
Fragments of a familiar structure—the House at the Edge of Time—stand at the edge of this island. Most of the building appears to have crumbled away, but what remains of the partially collapsed ruin is still recognizable as having once been part of Nyrissa’s home in Thousandbreaths.

All that remains of Nyrissa’s home is an L-shaped fragment missing most of its roof. Within, among the rubble (which functions only as difficult terrain, rather than the surrounding park’s greater difficult terrain), bits and pieces of the finery and decor from the nymph queen’s home remain, but little of value can be scavenged from the destruction.

@UUID[Actor.keCgklXcy4HZgQIL]

Moderate 20

Amid the rubble stand what appear to be three 8-foot-tall adamantine statues vaguely similar in appearance to Nyrissa. In truth, these are smaller-than-normal adamantine golems powered by the Lantern King’s own fury. While these golems are only Medium size, their statistics are those of elite adamantine golems, except that their attacks lack the normal 15-foot reach of a typical adamantine golem. Once the golems notice the PCs, fires flare up inside them and they all move to attack, plumes of smoke and flickers of flame churning in their hollow torsos or red-hot eye sockets. The three golems pursue foes relentlessly through the Park; as with the jabberwock, the writhing tangles of vegetation part for them as they advance, allowing the golems to ignore the greater difficult terrain (they do not ignore the difficult terrain inside of this ruined building).

@UUID[Actor.iqMMrq96o3c6D0vs]: Success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check made while @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU] the ruins of this structure uncovers a shard of a chalice’s cup—this is the third and final shard of the Apology, which can be recognized as detailed in area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t].

D4. Palace Approach.name: D4. Palace Approach
D4. Palace Approach.text: Once the PCs have all three shards of the Apology, they can readily see how the pieces of the vessel fit back together and reassemble it. If the reassembled @UUID[Item.NpsSQTqOdKsqfwCD] is brought to this location, the ground shakes and trembles as the world the Lantern King has made bursts into wisps of translucent shadow, forming and racing like a raging torrent back into the Apology. Again the world starts to shift, slowly as if it straining to decide which direction to go. A mass of animated vines and rubble suddenly surges forward from this spot, rising through the mists to form a winding spiral ramp that leads upward to the final isle above: the Palace.

The Palace.name: The Palace
The Palace.text:
If the PCs follow the winding pathway up to the Palace from area @UUID[.8Y896ivCvpkJrJFI], they arrive before a double door that opens automatically as they approach, allowing them to enter the throne room beyond. If the PCs reach these doors via other methods, such as via flight, the doors are locked tight. A @Check[type:thievery|dc:50|traits:action:pick-a-lock] check can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H], or a @Check[type:athletics|dc:50|traits:action:force-open] check can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx], but the doors themselves instantly heal damage inflicted to them. At your option, other powerful effects such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu] can open the doors. Teleportation effects can allow the PCs to enter the chamber beyond, as can spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.115Xp9E38CJENhNS], but unless they have multiple uses of this magic, doing so might simply end up trapping the PCs within the throne room with no escape route.

The sprawling throne room beyond the doors should be described as the same as the PCs’ own throne room back on the Material Plane, except in a devastating state of ruin. The rooms bordering this throne room are mostly for show—the doors should be difficult or even impossible to open unless you wish to expand this map for your game’s climactic battle.

Cracks radiate along the floor and walls of the throne room, while what appear to be perpetual fires burn along pillars and walls without consuming the structure. The thrones to the east look to be partially melted as if from some unimaginable heat, while vines of weird plants festooned with colorful flowers grow here and there as if nature itself were in the process of reclaiming the room.

Nyrissa: If the PCs didn’t slay Nyrissa and gained her support, they’ll find her here, a prisoner of the Lantern King. In this case, he’s transformed the second throne on the map into something akin to a birdcage, within which Nyrissa is kept. This cage has no door, but its bars can be destroyed (Hardness 35, HP 130 [BT 65]) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] with success on a @Check[type:athletics|dc:45|traits:action:force-open] check (this DC is reduced to @Check[type:athletics|dc:35|traits:action:force-open] if the bars are at their broken threshold). As long as Nyrissa remains trapped within the cage, she is powerless, but if the PCs can release her, she emerges from the cage at full power to fight at their side against the Lantern King and his agents. If the Lantern King is defeated and the PCs have @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber], the weapon is destroyed—Nyrissa regains her ability to love at this point, but this is only the first step of many toward her possible redemption.

  • @UUID[Actor.1vsQlCVwa9kVmgRi]
  • @UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]
  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]
  • @UUID[Actor.j7fPCy71EfQL1KmU]

Creatures

The Lantern King is a demigod, and as such is far too powerful a foe to face directly. Fortunately for the PCs, they won’t need to face him in person; the Lantern King has created a manifestation of his power within this room, an avatar of sorts, through whom he looks forward to speaking to the PCs. Initially, he appears in the form of a handsome, slender fey man with pointed ears and crown-like horns on his head. His armor and weapons evoke themes of a lit, glowing lantern, but all of this is merely for show; if a fight begins, he assumes his natural form—that of a 25-foot-diameter sphere of fire and light surrounded by twisting magical runes.

The Lantern King irreverently sits on one of the melted thrones, waiting for the PCs to arrive. He is attended by a number of fetch stalkers, each of whom has the form of one of the PCs (as such, the number of fetch stalkers in attendance should equal the number of PCs in the encounter). These fetch stalkers kneel to either side of the throne, obviously submissive to the Lantern King in mockery of the PCs themselves.

If Werendegar escorts the PCs, he takes his time introducing each of them to the Lantern King. You should take the time to call out two significant accomplishments for each PC at this time, making it seem almost like Werendegar is bragging about the PCs to the Lantern King, but once he has completed his introductions, he turns to the PCs and says “Yet despite your accomplishments, you are but ashes before the glory of a god,” before introducing the Lantern King himself. Werendegar then steps forward to take a silent position at the Lantern King’s side.

The Lantern King is frustrated that the PCs have disrupted the long, complex torments he’d put in place for Nyrissa, but a part of him has to admit that watching them grow in power and succeed against the nymph queen has been almost as entertaining. He hopes to draw some final fun from the PCs in this encounter, and perhaps even recruit them as his agents.

This encounter resolves over the course of three different stages—Introductions, Apologies, and Invitations. During each of these stages, the PCs interact with the Lantern King by attempting different skill checks to build up Victory Points to determine the final outcome of this climactic resolution to the Kingmaker Adventure Path. The PCs are free to throw caution to the wind and attack the Lantern King at any point, but if they do so before completing the three stages, they’ll face a much more dangerous fight. The Lantern King subtly encourages the PCs to lose their temper in the way he addresses them, hoping for a chance to test his avatar’s mettle against the heroes of the Stolen Lands.

In each of the three stages, each PC has a chance to attempt a single skill check to build up their total number of Victory Points. The amount of points they earn for each check follows this default scale:

  • Critical Success The PCs gain 2 Victory Points.

  • Success The PCs gain 1 Victory Point.

  • Critical Failure The PCs lose 1 Victory Point.

INTRODUCTIONS

Even if Werendegar escorted them into the throne room, the Lantern King is eager to hear from the PCs themselves about who they are and why they have come before him. He starts this stage with the following comment and challenge.

“You come before me as heroes of your world, yet you are still children before me. Tell me, each of you, what great deed have you accomplished that would suggest that my time is worth being spent entertaining you?”

At this point, each of the PCs has a chance to boast about what they feel is their greatest deed throughout the course of this campaign. Each can choose any skill of their choice to perform this boast, provided they justify its use. Since the skills used in the next two stages are specific ones, this is a chance for characters with other specialties to shine. Once all of the PCs have boasted, the Lantern King claps slowly in an almost mocking way, then goes on to claim responsibility for the PCs’ triumphs. After all, had he not set these events in motion by exiling Nyrissa, the PCs themselves would have had no “grand adventure” to become the heroes of.

Regardless of the skill chosen, it’s a DC 42 check to earn Victory Points.

APOLOGIES

The second stage begins with the Lantern King saying the following.

“Long ago, Nyrissa insulted the Eldest with her arrogance and pride, and so we punished her. Yet we are not without mercy. I bade her replace the thousand slights she put upon us with a thousand kingdoms drawn from a thousand worlds. Once the task was done, I would have accepted her apology and would have granted those thousand kingdoms eternal glory as part of a greater world than their own. Yet you ruined this. It strikes me that now, this final apology falls upon you to offer me. Do you regret meddling in my affairs, mortals? Will each of you apologize for tampering with events beyond your reckoning?

The Lantern King expects each PC to answer. He doesn’t necessarily expect an actual apology, although humility in this regard is an easier solution overall. As each PC replies, decide whether that character is honestly apologizing (and should therefore attempt a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:35] check), offering a dishonest or evasive apology (in which case they attempt a @Check[type:deception|dc:40] check), or refusing to apologize or demanding the Lantern King apologize for his actions instead (which necessitates a @Check[type:intimidation|dc:45] check). The Lantern King is amused by evasions and threats in this stage, but it’s tougher than simply apologizing to successfully entertain him that way.

Preventing Party Strife

There’s a potential for player-versus-player conflict in this final encounter, but such developments are certainly not for every group. By this time in the campaign, you should know your players and their characters well, and if you feel that any of the players would not enjoy having a betrayal take place, you should alter the Lantern King’s invitation to join him. Instead, he should offer the party the chance to escape—those who take his offer will be given the choice to be sent away to “safety” just before he begins his attack on the party. A PC who willingly accepts this offer is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ] to the Material Plane, but as is the Lantern King’s wont, he sends them to an entirely different planet than their home.

Alternately, you can simply omit the third stage of the conversation entirely; it’s just as easy to resolve the discussion with only two stages as with three.

INVITATIONS

Finally, the Lantern King raises a hand to his chin as he appears to consider his next words for a moment. After that moment, he speaks.

“You are each certainly notable and impressive mortals, I’ll give you that. But you are limited by your own nature. Behold, then, my magnanimity: cast aside your petty nation and join my side as my servants, and you shall become legends not just in your own paltry realm, but throughout all of reality itself!”

The Lantern King won’t reveal more of what he offers the PCs if they join his cause, and regardless of how the PCs react, they’ll each need to decide how they want to frame their answers to him: respectfully (with a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:40] check), aggressively (with an @Check[type:intimidation|dc:40] check), or deceitfully (with a @Check[type:deception|dc:40] check).

RESOLVING THE CONVERSATION

If the PCs make it through all three stages of the conversation without attacking the Lantern King, take a moment to total up their Victory Points to determine their overall success. If the PCs earned a total number of Victory Points equal to or greater than the number of PCs, then the Lantern King is impressed by them. More importantly, the fetch stalkers he keeps at his side that take their appearances from the PCs take note and realize that they are mere shadows of the PCs’ glory, and they do not join the Lantern King in the battle to come. If the PCs earned fewer Victory Points than the number of PCs, the Lantern King cannot hold back his derision. He mocks the PCs’ failure with a barrage of insults and laughter that continues for 2 rounds. If the PCs attack him during these two rounds, he’s startled enough by their sudden bravery that he rolls for Initiative with a flat check.

Fighting the Lantern King.name: Fighting the Lantern King
Fighting the Lantern King.text:
Effect

@UUID[Item.8YFwTTGCjd7tSI2A]

The Lantern King's appearance has been modified by the above effect. To reveal his true form, simply remove it from him!

Once the conversation resolves (including, in the case of a failure, two rounds of mockery and laughter during which the PCs do not attack the Lantern King), he rises up from his throne.

“Well then! After all of this, there’s only one more thing for it. You’ve come here to stand against a god, so who am I to deny you your closure?”

If any PC accepted his invitation to join his cause, he issues his first command to “defeat the fools among you who denied my offer!” This command carries no compulsion, and the PCs are free to choose to join on the Lantern King’s side to fight their fellow PCs. (If you adjusted the third stage to instead have the Lantern King offer the PCs a chance to flee, he instead offers those PCs the chance to be plane shifted back to the Material Plane.)

  • @UUID[Actor.1vsQlCVwa9kVmgRi]
  • @UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]
  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]
  • @UUID[Actor.j7fPCy71EfQL1KmU]

Encounter

Extreme 20

The Lantern King then attacks the party, rolling Intimidation for initiative as he transforms from his humanoid form into his true form—a roiling sphere of fire and runes. Having seen how the PCs hold up in conversation, he’s eager to both watch them in combat and to test out the strength of his avatar against what he hopes will be entertainingly challenging foes. His tactics in this fight are detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.3pWxyt1JN8VaDS2y] in @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8].

The Lantern King is joined in this fight by Werendegar (if the fey is present) and by the PC-appearing fetch stalkers at his side, unless the PCs managed to overwhelm those fetches as a result of the conversation. If so, the fetch stalkers step back, obviously fearful of the PCs, and begin the combat @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL] and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]; they continue to flee from the PC they resemble as long as they remain frightened, but they will not exit the throne room. Each round at the start of his turn while any of the fetch stalkers are fleeing, the Lantern King must succeed at a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. On a failure, he grows so angry and frustrated at his minions’ cowardice that his first action that turn must be to make a ranged Strike against one of the frightened fetch stalkers. If a fetch stalker is damaged in this way, it does not reduce its frightened condition at the end of its turn, and it is now fleeing from the Lantern King rather than the PCs.

A PC can attempt to recruit a frightened fetch stalker to their side by promising it mercy if the fetch aids them against the Lantern King.

Recruit Fetch Stalker 1

  • Auditory
  • Concentrate
  • Linguistic
  • Mental

You appeal to a fetch stalker that is at least frightened 1 and is within 60 feet of you, offering it mercy in return for its support in the fight against the Lantern King. Make a Deception, Diplomacy, or Intimidation check against the fetch stalker’s Will DC. If you attempt to recruit a frightened fetch stalker who has your appearance, you gain a +4 circumstance bonus on your check, and treat a Critical Failure as a Failure. The fetch stalker is then immune to Recruit Fetch Stalker using that skill check.

  • Critical Success The fetch stalker loses the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL] condition and the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D] condition and joins the PCs’ side for the remainder of the combat.

  • Success The fetch stalker loses the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D] condition for 1 round and joins the PCs’ side for that round. If it remains @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL] at the end of that round, it once again gains the fleeing condition.

  • Critical Failure The fetch stalker determines that the PCs aren’t that fearsome. It loses its @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL] and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D] conditions and joins the fight on the Lantern King’s side.

Repercussions: If the Lantern King’s avatar is defeated, he shrieks and howls in frustration and shame at having been bested by mortals, yet on some level the novelty of the situation amuses him greatly. His spherical body twists and churns into a vortex of light and fire that winds up through the throne room’s roof, blasting a hole through it to spiral upward and punch through the border of the Lantern Kingdom itself to be reabsorbed by the actual demigod who looms above. His amused chuckles echo down to the PCs below, a thundering sound that shatters the Lantern Kingdom to fragments. As the reality crumbles around the PCs, they are revealed to be back on the Material Plane at whatever location they were when they fell asleep and began the Hunting Dream at the start of this chapter.

If some (or even all) of the PCs sided with the Lantern King and he wins the fight, the Lantern Kingdom still collapses, but in this case, the PCs who sided with the Lantern King are instead brought with him into his realm in the First World to begin lives as his newest agents (see @UUID[JournalEntry.2X1qZWy3oCstxDsk.JournalEntryPage.rTzfbtnq6ismU3Tw]).

Concluding the Chapter.name: Concluding the Chapter
Concluding the Chapter.text:
Regardless of how this final encounter plays out, the story of Kingmaker draws to a close at its conclusion, but there may yet be repercussions awaiting the PCs, or opportunities for new adventures for new heroes. Potential ideas of where to go from here may be found in @UUID[JournalEntry.2X1qZWy3oCstxDsk].

If you don’t intend to continue your Kingmaker campaign, though, take some time at the end of this adventure to congratulate the players on what they’ve managed to accomplish along the way, particularly if they emerged victorious from this final epic encounter and put the Lantern King in his place.

One great way to end the campaign is to explain to the players that, for the following years after this campaign concludes, their kingdom thrived and prospered. You can use the ideas presented in @UUID[JournalEntry.2X1qZWy3oCstxDsk] here to describe new perils that the PCs faced and how they surmounted these challenges. At some point during this narrative-driven epilogue, though, you should go around the table and give each player a chance to provide a bit of information as to how their character spends the rest of their lives.

You and your group have shared an epic adventure together, after all, and it’s worth taking the time to appreciate your shared experience even as you prepare for your next game—whatever that game may be!

Elevating Your Epilogue with Audio

This module includes a @UUID[Playlist.BAuDoAthvOrAgMB8] Playlist which presents a medley arrangement of key songs from the Kingmaker Original Soundtrack, selected for the purpose of playing while you present the Epilogue of your game.

The conclusion medley has been carefully separated into 5 individual tracks intended to seamlessly blend together when played in order. We have included some suggestions on the kinds of things you may wish to include in your epilogue during certain tracks.

If you intend to write your epilogue to match the length of this playlist, it is worth keeping it to around 2000 words, in order to give yourself adequate time to read it. If you wish to increase the length of the conclusion playlist, it is best to add tracks from the @UUID[Playlist.lNg5gLEa8upd4fty] in between the other playlist portions. The conclusion audio tracks were specifically designed to anticipate this, so the transitions between individual tracks are less tightly controlled. You can also shorten the playlist by removing sections of the conclusion from the playlist.

Concluding Kingmaker Playlist - Total Length (29:48)

  • Introduction (4:24) - General summary, the return to the Kingdom and the Stolen Lands, the after-effects of the Lantern King's Defeat and the condition of the Kingdom. A time to reflect on how the party began their adventure and how far they've come since.

    • The Art of Ruling

    • Rule of Balance

    • The Beginning

  • Settlements (6:42) - The more specific consequences of the Lantern King's defeat on particular regions, how specific settlements are faring with the danger at an end, how communities outside the player kingdom have changed following the events.

    • Peacful Lands

    • The Tarnished Jewel (Pitax Theme)

    • Dawn at the Dunsward

    • The Shrike Hills

      Dawn at the Narlmarches

  • Characters (6:07) - How major NPCs have been changed over the course of the story, what those major NPCs will do next.

    • Bold Dog Barks Loudly

    • The Heart of the Land (Tavern Theme)

    • Rule of Chaos

    • Rule of Good

  • Antagonists (7:26) - Recap of the numerous major antagonists the party has faced, how they were defeated, whether they still live, hints at any future for them, and the aftermath effects of their defeat on the communities and regions surrounding them.

    • Bittersweet (Nyrissa's Theme)

    • The Laughing Lie (short interlude)

    • Dur Borba (Hargulka's Theme)

    • Relic Of A Crumbled Empire (Vordakai's Theme)

    • False Destiny (Armag's Theme)

    • The Proud, The Bitter, The Fallen (Nyrissa's Finale)

    • A String That Holds The World In Place (Lantern King's Theme)

  • Finale (5:09) - A final short summary of all that the party accomplished, and the relief of the adventure being at an end, what each party member will do now that they have established their kingdom.

    • Main Theme (short interlude)

    • The Coronation

    • Exploring the Stolen Lands

    • Kingmaker Main Theme (conclusion remix)

Twin Conclusions.name: Twin Conclusions
Twin Conclusions.text:
Assuming the PCs weren’t defeated themselves, the previous chapter ends in one of two ways: with Nyrissa’s death or with her being forgiven. In the unlikely event that she escapes, it’ll be only a matter of time before she tracks down the PCs and attempts to kill them again, giving the party another chance to defeat her or, perhaps, forgive her.

Regardless of how long it takes for either of these possible conclusions to occur, the Lantern King’s reaction to the event is the same, and he pulls the objects of his frustration—the PCs—into a self-contained reality known as the @UUID[.L8UvMkhoqamn3kBj]. What happens before the PCs experience the Hunting Dream depends on how they dealt with Nyrissa.

Nyrissa Slain

If the PCs killed Nyrissa, then all of Thousandbreaths, the House at the Edge of Time included, collapses and merges with the Material Plane as detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.geHtEMsUzqsld8cx.JournalEntryPage.k2Llwg0jHjCQQWfs]. Once all is said and done, the PCs are returned to their kingdom, standing before the ruins of the Castle of Knives. However, one thing is different: the now empty Apology sits on a slab of stone before them, shining and shimmering with power. Whether the PCs leave the Apology where it sits or take it with them is irrelevant, for the Lantern King destroys it the next time the PCs rest—as described in the @UUID[.L8UvMkhoqamn3kBj] below.

Nyrissa Forgiven

If the PCs forgive Nyrissa and spare her life, the defeated nymph queen becomes sorrowful and sullen. At this point, she morosely tells the PCs the tale of her rise and fall in power, of her failed attempt to challenge the Eldest, of how the Lantern King took her love to forge @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber], and of the Eldest’s promise to restore her place in the First World once she absorbed a thousand kingdoms into the Apology. If the PCs didn’t achieve a critical success at Forgive Foe to get to this point with her, they can impress upon her their forgiveness simply by saying so; no skill check is required unless the PCs are attempting to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ewwCglB7XOPLUz72] to her.

Nyrissa agrees to any PC demand to leave their kingdom in peace, and she does so honestly. Any treasures the PCs acquired while exploring her realm are theirs to keep, she adds—“Payment for your mercies,” as she puts it. She asks only that the PCs leave Briar with her, but if they refuse, she won’t press the matter again until the topic of the Lantern King’s reaction comes up (see below). Requests from the PCs for her aid in rebuilding their kingdom are met with a scoffing laugh unless the PCs can convince Nyrissa that they truly wish to help her and forgive her by adjusting her attitude to be friendly by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.OX4fy22hQgUHDr0q] (her initial attitude is unfriendly unless the PCs honestly forgive her, in which case her initial attitude is indifferent). If she’s made friendly, Nyrissa feels a faint glimmer of hope for the first time in a long time, and she cautiously tells the PCs that she’ll “consider the offer.”

At some point during the discussion, though, the subject of the Lantern King comes up. Nyrissa knows the demigod’s anger and frustration at her not filling the Apology is inevitable, and while she knows that he won’t be able to leave these developments alone, she’s not sure what form his frustration will take other than that it will certainly affect the PCs as much as—if not more than—herself. The PCs, she warns, should be ready for anything.

On the subject of Briar, Nyrissa knows the only way to regain her ability to love while she still lives is to have the Lantern King unmake the weapon. She bitterly observes that “if he can’t be convinced by words, my only hope is to convince him by force.” She agrees at this time to let the PCs to keep Briar for the short term if they promise to help her secure the Lantern King’s cooperation, but makes it abundantly clear that her hope is that the sword itself will soon be unmade.

Finally, regarding the Apology, Nyrissa admits that the artifact was given to her by the Lantern King and that the grains of sand within it each represent one of the 999 previously conquered kingdoms. She isn’t sure whether those absorbed kingdoms are destroyed, in stasis, or something else, and muses that if anyone knows, it would be the Lantern King. What she can explain to the PCs is that the process by which a mortal kingdom is conquered and then absorbed as a grain of sand is a mystery even to her, although she can (and sometimes has) granted certain people from kingdoms about to be absorbed mercy to remain as her minions at times in the past. If the PCs fear that the Apology can still be used to absorb their kingdom, Nyrissa truthfully tells them that, now that she has been forgiven, she has no intention of continuing to pursue this goal. While the wrath of the Lantern King is certainly coming, the PCs and their subjects no longer have anything to fear from Nyrissa herself.

Outcome.name: Outcome
Outcome.text:
Dream Defeat: If the wild hunt manages to kill all of the PCs, describe the final blow not as an attack, but as one of the members of the hunt (the monarch if he lives) raising the Apology over their head to smash it down upon the final PC. As it strikes the “killing blow” to that character, the Apology shatters and the grains of sand contained within surge outward in a vortex of chaos in which all of the PCs, be they “living” or “dead” at this point, feel 999 simultaneous existences in 999 simultaneous worlds filled with anguish and torment before everything goes dark. The PCs awaken in the Lantern Kingdom, as detailed at the start of @UUID[.BHJJrlOxFh1mhWhd], but when they do so, they are all @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv] as a result of dying in the Hunting Dream.

Dream Victory: If at least one PC remains alive to defeat the wild hunt, describe the final blow or spell that ends the last of the fey cutting through to smash against the Apology, which suddenly shatters in a blinding blast of golden light. The explosion results in the same disorienting vortex of chaos as described in Dream Defeat above. The PCs (including any who died during this fight) awaken in the Lantern Kingdom, as detailed at the start of @UUID[.BHJJrlOxFh1mhWhd], but as a result of their victory over the wild hunt, not only are none of the PCs doomed 1, but they are all restored to full health and capacity, as if they had benefited from a full night of rest and had just completed their daily preparations for the day’s adventures to come.

The Lantern King's Curse

At the end of the Hunting Dream, the Apology is shattered. This event occurs both in the Hunting Dream itself and in reality. As the Apology is shattered, the power of nine hundred and ninety-nine kingdoms at once are unleashed, allowing the Lantern King to instantly create a self-contained demiplane based on a theoretical apocalyptic future of the PCs’ kingdom in the Stolen Lands. The Lantern King invests a significant portion of his own being in this act, manifesting a living aspect of himself and also trapping the PCs and any of their companions within.

This is the curse of the Lantern King—that all who have ever sought the throne are doomed to wage eternal conflict, earning empty victories only to make the same war again tomorrow. To the PCs, the Lantern Kingdom appears as a shattered version of their own home, where they face familiar enemies they once thought they defeated. Simultaneously the defeated heroes of the other 999 kingdoms face their own apocalyptic nightmares as well, after enduring countless eons being trapped in a grain of sand. These realities exist atop each other but do not overlap—the PCs are unlikely to ever become aware of the true nature of the Lantern Kingdom, but regardless, they alone can do something to finally end this long-lasting torment.

Trapped in a Curse

Once the PCs escape the Hunting Dream, they become trapped in the Lantern Kingdom. This isn’t meant to cut them off from their companions entirely. As this part ends and the next part begins, work with your players to decide what companions, if any, they may wish to bring with them into the Lantern Kingdom. Those associated with the PCs’ classes, such as familiars or animal companions, should be allowed to accompany them even if they were not present when they were pulled into the dream. Whether or not you allow NPC companions to come with the PCs is left to you. The PCs can also bring with them any items they may have not had on them at the time they were drawn into the Hunted Dream. If the PCs have additional magic items they wish to craft, identify, or sell consider delaying the start of the Hunted Dream until the PCs can get these affairs in order, since once the next part begins, there’s no turning back!

Fetches.name: Fetches
Fetches.text:
A fetch is a twisted, deviant simulacrum of a humanoid creature that exists or existed at one point on the Material Plane. Rumors of fetches that are reflections of entities from other planes persist, but none of these tales speak of fetches that duplicate anything other than a sapient source. A fetch can manifest spontaneously when a powerful creature undergoes a significant emotional event or dies, either while on the First World or while in an area significantly influenced by the First World, but one can also be created by significant forces like the Eldest in order to torment and vex those who have annoyed them. While a fetch manifests from a soul’s “reflection,” and as such bears a striking resemblance to that creature’s appearance in life, a fetch has no true memories of its own. It keeps fragments of false remembrances from its source as if it experienced them in a half-remembered dream—which ensure the fetch is enraged by and jealous of its source.

A fetch is similar in appearance to the creature whose soul spawned it, save that it often displays fey-like features such as pointed ears, plantlike elements, or supernatural grace. A fetch who seeks to impersonate a still- living source must disguise these features, and takes care to manifest its fetch weapon as one known to be wielded by its target.

When a fetch dies, it and its manifested items fades away into a bloom of plant life, its soul instantly recycled into the First World, leaving behind a patch of weeds and thorny flowers roughly in the shape they held in mockery while alive.

Effect

Reflected Souls - @UUID[Item.awjNC3D6ORfNjsJk], @UUID[Item.oW0E3JKrZ9rFRVLz]

Most of the fetches encountered in this chapter were created from the souls of characters that are known to the heroes. In addition to the set encounters in the pages that follow, you're also encouraged to modify or add to these encounters in order to use characters that your players have become especially attached to.

This module provides alternate tokens for several characters which are intended to be used for fetches. To apply one of these tokens to a Fetch Stalker, you can drag the following effects onto them and choose the desired token from the list. Where the book specifies, we've already placed the effects as appropriate, but we've also provided the effect itself in case you want to make changes to the encounters.

The available options include the various Companions from the adventure and Companion's Guide, as well as several other prominent characters from the adventure. The available choices are listed in the descriptions of each effect.

Types of Fetch

@UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR] form from the souls of Medium or Small fey or humanoids (Small fetch stalkers have the same statistics as Medium ones.)

A @UUID[Actor.tjq87ghubOcPAXjj] is much larger than a stalker, and forms from the soul of a Large fey or humanoid.

Echoes of the corrupted soul of the undead can be used to spawn a fetch as well. A @UUID[Actor.6zWcjvPya0wWDZv2] appears more as its source did in life than as an undead.

Inversion of Undeath?

Scholars have theorized that fetches are a sort of inversion of undead, in that their creation is linked to a living creature’s soul—either forming when that soul has a powerful emotional event or manifesting alongside the creature’s death. Yet unlike an undead creature, a fetch is its own being, not a corruption or transformation of another creature’s soul. Fetches have souls themselves, yet since these souls are “borrowed” from energies underlying the First World, they have no capacity to gain in power once they are created. As such, fetches who live for any appreciable length of time grow increasingly frustrated with the stagnation of their personal growth, something of a curse that forces many to seek out increasingly dangerous risks. A fetch created from a still-living creature can, upon slaying its source, sometimes shed this limitation—in effect, taking the original’s place in reality. This drives most fetch to seek out their source, murder them in secret, and try to replace them, yet unless the original was as depraved and twisted as they, such deceptions are inevitably laid bare when a fetch’s evil nature becomes apparent.

Freed Fetches

If a fetch replaces its source by slaying them and taking their place in society, it can become a freed fetch. These are unique entities and should be hand-crafted as needed. All fetches begin their lives chaotic evil, but once they claim their place in the cycle of souls, they can (albeit rarely) find redemption. Fetches created by powerful entities after the source soul has moved on to be judged (including all fetches in Kingmaker) can never become freed, for they exist only at the whim of their creator.

Part 1: A Month of Destruction.name: Part 1: A Month of Destruction
Part 1: A Month of Destruction.text:
The PCs should be 17th level when this month of destruction begins.

It has been said that to look into the future and to see one’s fate is the surest way to meet it. Such worries have bothered @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD], who has long feared that heroes would come to her home and defeat her with a sword forged from her own fractured spirit. Though she has hoped this vision was but a nightmare, it was not until the Age of Lost Omens brought an end to the tyranny of prophecy that she began to hope that her future was not writ in stone.

Yet she is taking no chances. In order to fully deny this vision, she hopes to reclaim @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber], mend her own shattered spirit, and remove from existence the very weapon so long ago foretold to herald her death. Yet in taking these steps, she may have empowered the very heroes that could be her undoing.

Awakening Briar

If the PCs haven’t recovered @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber], you should give them a chance to do so by letting them further explore Irovetti’s palace, perhaps at the advice of an NPC ally if the PCs don’t seem eager to continue exploring the location. When the PCs recover the sword, it’s a +3 greater striking cold iron bastard sword—but as this chapter progresses, Briar becomes much more powerful, not only becoming a potent weapon against its source, Nyrissa, but also serving a critical role against the Lantern King himself in @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs].

The process of awakening Briar and its accumulating powers are detailed @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber].

Kingdom in the Background

When this chapter begins, the PCs’ kingdom has grown to encompass the majority of the Stolen Lands. Pitax has been welcomed into the nation, and the people of the kingdom are finally able to relax after the trauma of war recedes. Of course, a new threat is about to strike, but since the kingdom building part of the campaign has more or less concluded, you can simply run this chapter as-is without having to catch the players up on their kingdom’s growth.

The Calm Before.name: The Calm Before
The Calm Before.text:
The timing of when this chapter begins is left to you to decide.
