While the stone spire seems to be unnaturally tall, this is actually a strange visual distortion that affects creatures within 100 feet of the ground—the spire’s peak is in fact only 200 feet high.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.x9UldAAwoPhNLPU3], linked to the @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB] bloom.

@UUID[Actor.L3q7yQ0jKqH2IWy7]

Moderate 18

Perched atop the needle-like spire is what appears to be an enormous crow. This is one of the most notorious of Thousandbreaths’ denizens: the Nightmare Rook. This monstrous guardian of the skies above Thousandbreaths can visit the dreaming minds of outlanders who are foolish enough to sleep in Nyrissa’s realm, inflicting horrific living nightmares upon them. Yet it also serves as an expedient way to travel for many of the region’s creatures, for the Nightmare Rook is one of two creatures (the other being Nyrissa herself) that can fly above the trees of this realm.

The Nightmare Rook carries passengers only at Nyrissa’s direct request or as a result of magical control. It has excellent vision, and unless the PCs take pains to be stealthy as they enter this glade, the immense bird sees them and turns to face them as they approach. If they move more than a hundred feet into the clearing, it shrieks, spreads its wings, and swoops to attack.

The Nightmare Rook’s primary tactic is to split up the party by Snatching them and then flying to a different glade to drop them into the peril therein (it takes the Rook [[/r 2d6]] turns to reach another glade by flight, but it always takes it just one to return to its spire, regardless of how long it took to reach the other glade). The Rook is particularly fond of dropping victims into the Mire (@UUID[.xWZqVDCul4YpCaxc]) or the Fruiting Orchard (@UUID[.1pH3Z4bzZ12uCY78]). Thousandbreaths prevents creatures from being dropped into the woods themselves; a character who’s dropped anywhere other than a glade falls [[/r 2d10×10]] feet but finds themselves somehow landing at the same spot they were Snatched up from. The Rook returns to this glade as long as PCs remain within to repeat this process until it is reduced to fewer than 250 HP, at which time its frustration takes over and it lands to finish the fight with its spells and melee Strikes. It saves alter reality to duplicate a spell needed to remove a debilitating effect on itself as needed. If reduced to 90 or fewer HP, the Nightmare Rook calls for surrender and promises to fly the PCs to any glade they wish if they spare its life. Of course, this is a lie, as any PC who sees through its deception can tell. Any PCs who take the Rook up on this offer are brought to the Mire or the Fruiting Orchard (equal chances of either), whereupon it Bucks to dislodge its riders into the glade below before returning to its perch here to recover from the fight.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB] bloom (page 432) hasn’t been defeated, the Nightmare Rook gains the elite adjustments and becomes a 21st-level creature.

E. The Fruiting Orchard.name: E. The Fruiting Orchard
E. The Fruiting Orchard.text:
A thirty-foot-high brick wall encircles a large clearing in the woods. Within, the riot of growth continues, but a tangle of mushrooms and fungus grow amid various tropical plants. Bulbs of brightly colored fruits the size of a human head hang from or grow on the trunks of many of the trees—and many of these bulbs twitch and pulse as if something within were attempting to escape.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.JKCns3BRL7EgQBM4] linked to the @UUID[.E88t1oiqChbJ9PXI] bloom.

@UUID[Actor.pfvUhfy0VHNlTyvN]

Moderate 18

This noxious orchard is where Nyrissa allows the “children of Thousandbreaths”—hundreds of thousands of tiny mandragoras—to dwell. The bulbous “fruits” on the mushrooms are in fact growing mandragoras nearing “birth.”

While this garden is infested with mandragoras, just as the Shrieking Children bloom was infested, these mandragoras do not attack intruders as a swarm. Instead, they crawl together into an immense mound, leaving the tropical plants behind as they quickly spread their malleable bodies together to form a single 35-foot-tall mandragora.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.E88t1oiqChbJ9PXI] bloom hasn’t been defeated, the PCs face two mandragora swarms here as well.

F. The Shunned Falls.name: F. The Shunned Falls
F. The Shunned Falls.text:
A waterfall cascades between two immense stone hands carved from the peak of a stony cliff, tumbling into a large pool in this two-hundred-foot diameter forest glade. The pool is crystal clear, its shores thick with reeds and water-flowers of dazzling hue. Several large leaves the size of small boats float near the pool’s shore, while immense glowing fireflies the size of human hearts bob and weave lazily in the air above.

The Shunned Falls is unique among the glades of Thousandbreaths in that it does not generate a bloom in the Stolen Lands, for this is the one place in Thousandbreaths that had already fallen from Nyrissa’s direct control. It is here that evidence of her shame and guilt persists—a constant reminder to her that no matter how powerful she thinks she can become, the Eldest are more powerful still. As a result, Nyrissa hates this glade with a passion and rarely, if ever, visits here. Once the glade’s current denizens (see below) leave, it can be a safe place for beleaguered PCs to camp—Nyrissa and her minions do not intrude upon this region.

The large leaves that float on the water can serve as impromptu rafts for characters who wish to float downstream on the river. The large fireflies are harmless, but success on a @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge], @Check[type:nature|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge], or @Check[type:religion|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check notes that fireflies are sacred to the Lantern King.

@UUID[Actor.xqTVUqUs5UsGcSuH]

Moderate 18

A mated pair of flying owlbears dwells here. While intelligent enough to understand Sylvan, the winged owlbears are little more than wild beasts as far as denizens of the First World are concerned and exist here simply because the glade is otherwise uncontrolled. They rise up to defend their territory as soon as they notice the PCs, fighting to the death.

G. The Mire.name: G. The Mire
G. The Mire.text:
The trail ends at a great space in the forest that opens up into a foul-smelling marsh perhaps a mile or so across.

The mire’s waters average 10 feet deep, but numerous crisscrossing troughs drop to depths of 30 feet throughout the swamp. Likewise, a maze of ridges that rises to within inches of the water surface (but average 1 foot below it) wind throughout the mire; a character can move through the mire along these ridges treating them as difficult terrain, but any character who makes more than one Move action in a round while walking along these ridges must succeed at a @Check[type:acrobatics|dc:30] check or slip off the edge of the ridge into one of the 30-foot-deep troughs.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.x3r5hAzgXxZN8IFD], linked to the @UUID[.lCpKc2S7LiEpQmgd] bloom.

@UUID[Actor.iD3YlM0QzI2SrjD6]

Moderate 18

This bog is normally the den of he Wriggling Man, but Nyrissa asked him to join her in her home while she prepares to absorb the Stolen Lands. Yet the Wriggling Man has not left his swamp unguarded—four immense mire worms swim through the waters of the marsh, and they quickly surge forth to attack anyone who enters the glade.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.lCpKc2S7LiEpQmgd] bloom hasn’t been defeated, the PCs face an additional two mire worms here.

H. The Knurly House.name: H. The Knurly House
H. The Knurly House.text:
The forest opens into a narrow clearing surrounded by bent, extremely broad trees. At the center of the clearing rises a strange sight: what appears to be two dozen different houses tangled together in a semi-organized mess, forming a conglomerate building where right angles seem unwelcome. A tangled yard filled with bristly vines and thorns surrounds the cottage.

This building is the Knurly House, all that remains of Nyrissa’s first attempt to craft herself a house from the raw potential of the First World. She learned much from this initial attempt, and the House at the Edge of Time is a much more stable and well-organized affair.

The thorns that surround the Knurly House are 20 feet thick and 15 feet tall, save for a 10-foot-wide path leading to the house itself. A creature can move through the thorns but treats the overgrown area as both difficult terrain and hazardous terrain that deals [[/r 4d6[piercing]]] damage each time the creature takes a Move action.

Bloom Trophies: Two-foot-long vines of tangled, @UUID[Item.IZTr2HwEIRbBSwF2], linked to the @UUID[.vTHOtZdnJXb9mKnP] bloom.

Nyrissa gave this house to one of her few true friends, a powerful hag cleric of the goddess Gyronna. This twisted annis hag has abandoned and forgotten her true name in favor of being known as the Knurly Witch. When the Knurly Witch first stumbled into Thousandbreaths 220 years ago, Nyrissa offered the annis a choice—die and feed her pet tarn linnorm, or live as Nyrissa’s servant. The annis made the choice easily enough and does not regret it, for she has been treated well by Nyrissa. Over the centuries, Thousandbreaths has accepted her as one of its own, and she now functions as a native to the demiplane.

Although the Knurly Witch is as evil as they come, she doesn’t immediately attack. She’s been warned of the PCs by Nyrissa, and she’s curious. She invites the PCs up to share tea with her as soon as she spots them. If the PCs agree to the invitation, the Knurly Witch adopts a strangely forthcoming and honest tactic as she serves them “tea.” A successful @Check[type:perception|dc:40] check is enough for a PC to realize the mixture isn’t actually tea. A PC that imbibes this foul mixture of crow’s blood and powdered maggots must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:38] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18] (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18] on a critical failure). She simply starts asking the PCs what they’re doing here in Thousandbreaths and tries to discern their powers, their goals, and their weaknesses through blunt questioning. If she thinks that it’ll make the PCs more cooperative, she proposes a free trade of information: for each question of hers they answer, she’ll answer one of theirs about Nyrissa. Of course, the Knurly Witch lies with each answer, trying to feed the PCs completely false information about the nymph queen in hopes that even if they believe one of her lies, their tactics will be compromised in a later confrontation. Eventually, either the Knurly Witch or the PCs are likely to grow tired of this, at which point the Knurly Witch can roll for initiative with a Deception check (she rolls with Perception if the PCs simply attack her on sight).

The Knurly Witch

Moderate 18

On the first round of combat, the Knurly Witch casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.b5sGjGlBf58f8jn0] and moves upward out of reach of foes on the ground. She casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.jSRAyd57kd4WZ4yE] the next round to summon a @UUID[Actor.NTXm3ee7WZJ92Sww], then uses her ranged spells against the PCs on the following rounds. If reduced to 250 Hit Points, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2Vkd1IxylPceUAAF]. Upon being reduced to 100 HP or less, she activates @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.nzbnTqHgNKiGZkrZ] to retreat to her sanctuary in the House at the Edge of Time (area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc]). There, she seeks out Nyrissa to report her failure to defend the Knurly House and prepares as mentioned in area K16 to confront the PCs one last time.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.vTHOtZdnJXb9mKnP] bloom hasn’t been defeated, the PCs also face a particularly powerful @UUID[Actor.xZf1oOzxRrSON6Lb] here—a monster who does his best to prevent any PC from approaching the Knurly Witch to fight her in melee.

@UUID[Actor.6ScEXKMZcWih1rKu]: A search of the Knurly House takes an hour. With success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check, a PC discovers one of the treasures the Knurly Witch hid; a critical success discovers all four. These treasures consist of several journals written in Aklo that contain the formulas for two rituals (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7yWXx3qC4eFNHhxD] and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.nzbnTqHgNKiGZkrZ]), a set of greater holy prayer beads, a +2 greater striking wounding dagger, and a ring of wizardry IV.

I. The Baleful Lantern.name: I. The Baleful Lantern
I. The Baleful Lantern.text:
This small clearing is lit by ghastly yellow-green light that flickers like torchlight. The sources of the light are dozens of human heads that hang by their hair from spikes on the outer edge of a towering beehive-shaped structure in the center of the clearing—these heads function as horrific lanterns, with the light emerging from empty eye sockets and gaping mouths. Worse, the eyes and lips of several of these grisly lanterns seem to be twitching and writhing as if in pain.

This building is the home of one of Thousandbreaths’ most hateful denizens: the Misbegotten Troll. The dozens of severed heads that decorate his strange home are the remains of his previous meals, unfortunate victims harvested over the past several hundred years. The glowing light is little more than an eerie side effect of the minor necromantic enhancement that makes the heads function as lanterns—the souls of these unfortunate victims have long since moved on.

Up until the month of destruction begins, the Misbegotten Troll served as the tether for this glade, but for the duration of this chapter that tether has been transferred to the building itself—the Baleful Lantern. If the PCs understand the nature of the glade tethers (by reaching at least 18 Research Points while investigating Thousandbreaths), success on a DC 38 check to Identify Magic while studying the structure reveals that the destruction of the Baleful Lantern will break this glade’s tether.

The Baleful Lantern is AC 30, has Hardness 20, and has 400 HP (200 BT). If reduced to its Break Threshold, the structure creaks and groans; at this point a @Check[type:athletics|dc:43|traits:action:force-open] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] its load-bearing metal bars can cause the entire thing to collapse. When the Baleful Lantern is destroyed, the collapse inflicts [[/r 20d6[bludgeoning]]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:35|basic:true] save) to all creatures inside of it or within 30 feet of its exterior.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.54HZ0h9J3LGkm4Lt] from the chain of lovelies, linked to the @UUID[.Eg1AzaavQmg6VbK7] bloom.

@UUID[Actor.ndoXVn6MPPxSJvcC]

Moderate 18

The Misbegotten Troll left a pack of eight black smilodons to guard his home while he’s out rampaging. If the PCs come to this area after defeating the troll on the Material Plane, these beasts are frenzied and eager for anything, and they attack on sight.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.Eg1AzaavQmg6VbK7] bloom hasn’t been defeated, the troll is instead encountered here as he feeds on a huge platter of a few dozen unfortunate grigs.

J. The High Folly.name: J. The High Folly
J. The High Folly.text:
Thousands of mossy stone statues, each depicting a different creature, stand in this grassy clearing. At the clearing’s center rises a low but strangely round hill, atop which rises a three-hundred-foot-high tower of white stone.

This glade contains the High Folly, a gatehouse that watches over the only path that leads to Nyrissa’s home. The field of statues is an entire army of petrified First World monstrosities—a stone army that Nyrissa has been collecting with the aid of her medusa ally Phomandala (see area @UUID[.8sZ4iXozKx9wHzp8]) for many years. When the @UUID[.iGUBEHB2bWskpRFL] begins on day 26 of the month of destruction, this final bloom restores this army to flesh, and they are unleashed upon the PCs’ capital city. Here on the First World, though, they are harmless. If the PCs have already defeated the War of the High Folly bloom, this clearing is empty of statues, and only the white stone tower—the High Folly itself—remains.

The High Folly is a hollow tower within which a single curving stairway rises to an observation platform under open roofs—the structure and purpose of the tower is similar to the leaning tower in @UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN], but a character who looks out from this tower’s observation platform can see all of Thousandbreaths laid out below—almost exactly how the @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg.JournalEntryPage.71I38vDWfJaf8A1g] at the end of Zuddiger’s Picnic shows.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.2OZvR3q1KRX0PR6a] taken from the scar left by the High Folly’s passing, linked to the @UUID[.iGUBEHB2bWskpRFL] bloom.

Ilthuliak terrorized the River Kingdoms of Pitax and Mivon as well as Numeria and Brevoy in her youth. She murdered and ate all would-be dragonslayers who hunted her, eventually attracting Nyrissa’s attention. The nymph wooed Ilthuliak to relocate her lair to the High Folly with promises of power, treasure, and glory soon after the Stolen Lands drew her attention about two decades ago—and so far, Nyrissa has made good on those promises.

@UUID[Actor.n82GZhM6joceE91v]

Severe 18

Ilthuliak remains vigilant at all times in the shadows atop the High Folly, a light sleeper and a keen observer as she looks out over the surrounding glade. If she notices the PCs approaching, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx], then uses that opportunity to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wfleiawxsfhpRRwf], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OOELvfkTedBMlWtq], and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.uqlxMQQeSGWEVjki], while positioning herself in the air so she can use her breath weapon to maximum potential on the first round of combat when time stop ends. She opens combat with her breath weapon, following up with a few rounds flying overhead and casting spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.37ESlJzUvVbOudOT], @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2w4OpAGihn1JSHFD], and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qDjeG6dxT4aEEC6J]. Once her breath weapon has recharged, she swoops down to land amid the PCs to make good use of it, then loses herself in the glory of melee battle, periodically taking to the sky to cast a few more spells. Ilthuliak fights to the death.

@UUID[Actor.O1Jd6pN97AFJlmw9]: Ilthuliak’s treasure lies atop the High Folly in an impressive mound at the center of the observation platform. This hoard consists of 57,000 cp, 4,800 sp, 1,900 gp, 120 pp, a silver scepter set with strips of jet and ivory worth 250 gp, a darkwood jewelry box worth 100 gp that contains a tangle of costume jewelry and one necklace of precious gems worth 1,200 gp, a strange chunk of amber in which is trapped a mosquito that seems to have tiny hands at the tips of its feet (this strange bauble is worth 900 gp as long as the truth of it being a fanciful hoax remains obscured—a successful DC 35 Crafting check reveals the truth and its actual price of 5 gp), and assorted additional gemstones and minor trinkets worth an additional 1,000 gp. In addition, her lair contains several potent magic items: a +2 greater striking returning thundering starknife, bracers of armor type II, a cassock of devotion, a cloak of the bat, a moderate thurible of revelation, a rod of negation, and a circlet of persuasion.

Part 3: House at the Edge of Time.name: Part 3: House at the Edge of Time
Part 3: House at the Edge of Time.text:
The PCs should be 19th level before they enter the House at the Edge of Time.

At Thousandbreaths’ heart lies a House; yet this is no mortal edifice. Raised from the very fabric of reality in the First World at the height of Nyrissa’s power before her paramour was exiled and her love was taken from her, this mansion is known as the House at the Edge of Time for its timeless quality. It has existed unchanged for Thousandbreaths’ long existence, whereas the glades themselves shift and change to match Nyrissa’s needs and interests. On one side, the House overlooks the panorama of Thousandbreaths, while the other side looks out over time and space—an endless gulf of stars and blackness shifting between mountains that rise and fall as if erosion took but the span of a single breath to reshape the land, giving the impression that the House stands at the literal edge of Time itself.

The Final Glade.name: The Final Glade
The Final Glade.text:
The forest path opens at the shore of a vast lake, its waters still and dark. A stone bridge crosses the lake to an island at its center, where a walled gatehouse bars entry to the isle beyond. Beyond the gatehouse looms a sprawling manor, its steep roofs and twin towers stretching up into the sky. The tops of these towers seem to shift and shimmer, sometimes appearing to be simple stone edifices and other times being crowned with twisted, twitching trees or sinister-looking foliage. Likewise, the far side of the lake flickers and shimmers, one moment featuring images of vast mountains, the next featuring the endless expanse of the night sky, as if reality itself isn’t sure what it wants to be.

While in Thousandbreaths, the lake surrounding the House is effectively bottomless. Just as one can fly upward and never rise above the tree level, one can swim down into the lake without ever reaching the bottom. Fortunately the surface is never more than a few hundred feet away should a swimmer elect to return, despite the fact that the lake itself seems to be a mile across. The lake spills over the edge of its mesa in two places, to the left and right, to form the twin nameless rivers that frame Thousandbreaths and eventually meet again at the Whirling Lake, where the waters drain away to nowhere. If Thousandbreaths is uprooted, the waterfalls soon run dry as the lake drains to equilibrium—this results in a surface height change of only 20 feet. Additionally, the lake gains a bed at this time, although at 150 feet, it is still quite deep.

Scene

@UUID[Scene.e3aUzjPZMnu8fK7G]

This scene depicts the bridge connecting the House to Thousandbreaths.

The House can be reached via a long stone bridge that connects its island to the mesa’s edge. A flight of stairs rises up from the lakeshore to the bridge, which itself runs at a height of forty feet above the water. A gatehouse flanked by towers guards the far side’s entrance to the House, while in the courtyard beyond, tall dark trees rise and rustle in the constant soft breeze. Dozens of windows stare out of the House itself, and stone fey hang from every gable. The outline of the House is as beautiful as it is dangerous, with knifelike crenellations, spear-topped towers, and eaves and shingles made of blades. Some parts of the House seem new and others old, but the structure as a whole is ancient and unchanging—even the sections of the House that appear to be ruins have always been that way (with exceptions noted in the text).

A PC who studies the two towers extending above the manor’s roofs and succeeds at a @Check[type:nature|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check notes that the treelike vegetation that shifts in and out of reality atop the taller towers is a sort of visual projection from the First World, suggesting a concentration of primal magic there. A critical success on this check identifies the “tree” atop the shorter tower as a powerful sard (unless this creature has been relocated to the courtyard—see areas @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2] and @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]).

  • @UUID[Actor.2IrbfdtWyXiGOLBA]

Approaching the House

Moderate 19

Regardless of whether the PCs use the bridge, swim, boat, or fly to the House, the approach is well protected. A tarn linnorm named Tarlaxian dwells in the lake, and it watches those who fly above its waters or cross the bridge. Tarlaxian won’t pursue the PCs into the House itself, but he does encamp on the bridge to serve as a menacing guard against any attempt to flee the manor, ready to resume the attack if the PCs emerge. If the PCs attempt to use ranged attacks or spells against him from within the safety of the House, Tarlaxian simply retreats back into the waters of the lake.

House Features.name: House Features
House Features.text:
Raised Alarms

The occupants of the House at the Edge of Time are aware of the PCs and await their arrival, so the structure’s defenders are already on high alert. If the alarm is raised, all of the House’s occupants become hypervigilant, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus on initiative checks for the next 24 hours.

The House at the Edge of Time exists in the past and the future, the maybe and the never. One room may be clean and bright while others are collapsing and decayed. Some have been damaged by the arrival of the PCs who slew Nyrissa yesterday and will do so tomorrow in this land of the impossible. Yet as strange as this warping of time may be, stranger still is the fact that such ripples and transformations remain constant, as if a storm of fractured time tore through the structure, only to be frozen forever in the middle of a chaos of a hundred different eras. This is how the House was when Nyrissa created it so long ago, and how it remains.

Doors, Walls, and Windows: The outer walls are covered in ironwood vines that have grown over the windows, effectively barring them. While these vines make climbing the walls easy (@Check[type:athletics|dc:10|traits:action:climb] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]), they make breaking in through windows very difficult, as the vines are Hardness 22 and have 100 HP (BT 50). A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] the vines allows someone to bend and rip a hole in the vines large enough to admit a Medium creature. Anyone climbing the House’s outer walls quickly attracts the attention of the creatures that dwell atop the ivy tower (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]), or the denizen of the courtyard (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]).

All of the doors in the House are wooden. Each is carved with images of laughing, frowning, or frightened faces and open with a touch unless otherwise indicated. All stairwells in the House are steep and function as difficult terrain. Ceiling height in the House itself is 10 feet unless otherwise indicated in the text.

Helix Theorem: A PC who was present in the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth when the Helix Theorem was successfully performed (see @UUID[JournalEntry.45g079GlbehLJpmo.JournalEntryPage.ZPtDIkEsiwPp3Gem]) gains additional protection in the House at the Edge of Time, as the theorem bolsters their temporal presence in the flow of time. Any PC who is thus protected automatically realizes that the theorem protects them the first time they set foot in the House at the Edge of Time as they experience a disturbing sense of déjà vu and a “memory” that almost feels as if they’re remembering something in the future that hasn’t yet happened to them. At this point, the PCs know that they have gained a +4 status bonus on all saving throws made against teleportation effects or attempts to banish them to another plane while in the House at the Edge of Time. Additional protections manifest during a few specific encounters as well, as detailed below—when these occur, the PCs experience the same brief déjà vu and strange memories of the future, alerting them that their exposure to the Helix Theorem has protected them.

In addition, any PC who is protected by the Helix Theorem in this way knows that they can reflexively shed this protection in order to manipulate time itself once only. The PC gains the following free action as long as they are in the House at the Edge of Time and is protected by the Helix Theorem.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.adventure-specific-actions.Item.LRuwz61jNmIfQYby] F

Trigger You fail or critically fail a saving throw, are hit by a Strike, or would increase your @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yZRUzMqrMmfLu0V1] condition’s value.

Requirements You are located in the House at the Edge of Time (including any of Nyrissa’s fables) and are currently under the protection of the Helix Theorem.

You shed the timeline you currently occupy, then return to it once the triggering event passes. The exact effects depend on the nature of the triggering effect, as detailed below. You are no longer protected by the Helix Theorem; once this protection is lost, it cannot be regained.

Failed Saving Throw: Shift the degree of success up from Failure to Success, or a Critical Failure up to a Failure, for the triggering saving throw.

Hit by a Strike: If the triggering Strike was a Critical Success, change it to a Success. If the triggering Strike was a Success, change it to a Failure.

Increase to Dying Condition: Instead of increasing your dying condition, you lose the dying condition.

Phantoms: The House is full of phantoms of yesterday and tomorrow. They can be glimpsed in mirrors, the scent of their perfume lingers at times in the air, and the meals they have yet to eat lie steaming on the table. The PCs are occasionally able to see or hear these phantoms, if only briefly. These phantoms can variously be of people and creatures they do not recognize, but now and then the phantoms draw from the PCs’ own minds, pasts, and futures—these phantoms might remind the PCs of allies, old enemies thought dead, or even younger or older versions of themselves. In some cases, these temporal phantoms can actually interact with the present—the text of the encounter provides details as to where these effects can occur. In others, you should feel free to liven up an otherwise empty room with a strange glimpse of something half-seen or partially heard as you see fit.

Static Time: Features in the House can be altered (walls destroyed, doors bashed down, windows broken, furniture burnt, and denizens slain), but the contents of the House periodically “reset” as long as Nyrissa still lives. This reset occurs each time the PCs leave Thousandbreaths for any amount of time, unless they manage to uproot the demiplane. In this case, with the House’s glade being the only part remaining, the reset occurs 24 hours after the PCs leave the House; if the PCs return before this time passes, the reset doesn’t occur and the next time they leave, the 24-hour “countdown” begins anew.

When the House resets, broken doors reform, windows become unbroken, destroyed and disarmed traps rebuild themselves, and so on. Any resident of the House is restored to full Hit Points, and any ongoing affliction or magical effect that hampers them is subjected to a counteract attempt by the House, which has a 10th-level counteract check of [[/r 1d20+35]]. Residents that are killed remain dead, and when the PCs next return, any remains left behind have decayed away to skeletons as if years had passed. Residents that have been relocated to another plane entirely are similarly not restored by the House’s reset. Any items (such as treasure) the PCs brought with them out of the House when it resets do not vanish, but upon returning to the rooms where they found these items, the PCs discover phantasmal images of the removed items lingering in the places where they were originally found.

Warped Dimensions: Time is not the only thing that’s warped in the House—the dimensions themselves are as well. In most cases, these manifest as strange curiosities, such as the elevation change in the courtyard not being reflected in the surrounding House itself, or the inverted storeroom at area @UUID[.GTFGgSdMJ5uJIMCj], or simply the fact that while some of the rooms have different ceiling heights or floor depths when explored, the exterior of the House suggests each floor has a constant level.

Of greater concern, though, is how teleportation effects function in the House. When a visitor to the House attempts any teleportation action, allow them a @Check[type:perception|dc:40] (master) check (or @Check[type:perception|dc:35] for any PC under the influence of the Helix Theorem) to notice something strange going on with the magic as they begin the action—the effect simply seems “off.” The PC can halt the action at this point without losing the resource to teleport. If the PC doesn’t notice the strange sensation or proceeds to take the action anyway, they activate the House’s teleport trap. This trap does not affect any natives to Thousandbreaths or the House itself (including those like the Knurly Witch who have acclimated to the demiplane over time).

@UUID[Actor.hW40C78kV4MBDs4v]

Simple Hazard 19

The House at the Edge of Time folds time and space back on the target, who teleports painfully into their own body an instant before they travel.

Nyrissa’s Revenge.name: Nyrissa’s Revenge
Nyrissa’s Revenge.text:
Nyrissa doesn’t take an active part in the defense of her House until the PCs confront her in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]. Until then, she focuses on preparing to absorb the Stolen Lands into the Apology.

If the PCs have already defeated this plan, either by enduring the month of destruction or by uprooting Thousandbreaths, Nyrissa’s plans shift to vengeance. The PCs have foiled her plans, but if she can defeat them and recover @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber], she hopes that she might be able to sidestep the final kingdom needed to fill the Apology. As long as the PCs remain in the House, she bides her time in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK], but if the PCs retreat back to the Material Plane, Nyrissa sends agents to attack them. She draws these agents from the First World via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZc8ZwtsyWnxUUW0], calling upon four of her defaced nymphs to serve as secondary casters.

  • @UUID[Actor.edP108Bh51Ktxn9T]
  • @UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]
  • @UUID[Actor.ap9Q8j7pjLAhHHSZ]

Nyrissa's Revenge

Low 19

Nyrissa performs this ritual in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK], which alters the way the ritual functions. Here, the chance to perform primal call is a DC 35 check. The ritual, if successful, manifests a creature from Thousandbreaths itself. Nyrissa must still expend ingredients when she performs the ritual. If Thousandbreaths has been uprooted, this energy is drawn instead from the House at the Edge of Time—all that remains in the demiplane. In this case, Nyrissa and the defaced nymphs suffer a –4 circumstance penalty to their skill checks to perform the ritual.

Nyrissa always performs this @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZc8ZwtsyWnxUUW0] ritual at 10th level. She uses it to call an elite primal bandersnatch, elite sard, or elite terotricus, varying her choice each time so that the PCs won’t quite know what to expect. Each attempt at the ritual costs her 200 gp in resources, drawn from the supplies in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]; she has enough supplies to attempt the ritual 10 times. She doesn’t need to offer additional payment to the creature, and she sends it on its way into the Material Plane to track down and attack the PCs. The creature manifests at the Castle of Knives (encounter site @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]) in Thousand Voices. How it tracks down and attacks the PCs is left to you to determine.

Nyrissa continues performing primal call rituals in this way daily. Once she depletes her resources for casting the ritual, or once she rolls a critical failure on her check, she can no longer pursue this avenue of vengeance. Unwilling to leave her demiplane or to risk the House’s actual guardians, Nyrissa now turns her attention to hunkering down and waiting out the PCs. It’ll take her years to refocus her attentions on a new kingdom on a different world to attempt to gain her final apology—if it comes to this, the PCs can simply leave her alone and this chapter concludes. Yet the campaign continues, for the Lantern King himself grows impatient if this stalemate continues for too long—see @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs] for details.

K1. Gatehouse.name: K1. Gatehouse
K1. Gatehouse.text:
A stone gatehouse bars entry into the sprawling manor’s courtyard beyond with a lowered portcullis. In the walls above, arrow slits leer down while a forty-foot-high wall extends from the gatehouse in both directions to connect to two more towers.

The iron portcullis (Hardness 18, HP 72 [BT 36]) can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:38] check. Alternately, it can be raised or lowered from the upper floor of the gatehouse (area K1b). Although there are several guards posted here and along the wall, the denizen of the courtyard (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]) comes to defend the area if it notices anyone breaking into area K1a.

@UUID[Actor.gXbDaY9ci2u22ptT]

Moderate 19

Undead are rare in the First World, for it is a realm infused with life, but here in the House at the Edge of Time that overabundance of life is muted. Nyrissa’s house guards are thankful for this because they are ghosts. Once members of an ancient elven kingdom on a distant world, these elves were the first victims of Nyrissa’s quest to claim a thousand kingdoms. She has never been able to replicate the transformation of a nation’s greatest warriors into ghostly guards like this since that first conquest, but since these ghosts rejuvenate as long as Nyrissa lives, she’s never had need for reinforcements.

As ghosts, these guards are eternally vigilant; they need not take breaks to eat, sleep, or entertain themselves. At any one time, four stand guard in area K1b, one atop each of the towers (areas K1c and K1d), and one atop each of the walls to either side of the gatehouse, amounting to eight ghostly guards in all.

When these ghosts spot intruders, they use their frightful moan more as an alarm than an attack, then they proceed to use Ectoplasmic Maneuver to attempt to disarm the intruders. After a few rounds, four of the ghosts swoop down to engage the PCs in melee while the other four fly up to make ranged attacks. The ghostly guards fight until destroyed.

K2. The Great Courtyard.name: K2. The Great Courtyard
K2. The Great Courtyard.text:
This large courtyard is a two-tiered region covered with thick grass. Paths wind to and from various doors, and a single, wide flight of stairs allows easy access to the courtyard’s second tier, where several towering oak trees loom over the main body of the House.

A subtle but strange warping of reality exists within the boundaries of this courtyard—while the main body of the House is all on the same level as the upper tier, the entrance to area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT] lies on the same level as the lower tier despite the fact that one can walk from area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT] to K2 via the House without seeming to change elevation. The branches of the tallest tree in the courtyard (the one just south of area @UUID[.WSfWb1KkPdkDeB0g]) are one of the four entrances to the Fable—they lead to area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK] (see that area for how one can enter the Fable via this tree’s branches).

  • @UUID[Actor.XQyXoOe7FCpZilaF]
  • @UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]

Encounter

Varies 19

The guardian of the Great Courtyard is a huge and dangerous creature—but its nature depends on whether the PCs have already encountered and slain the lesser jabberwock at the end of Part 1. If the events of @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt] have yet to occur, then the lesser jabberwock still lurks here amid the trees of the courtyard’s upper tier. If, on the other hand, the lesser jabberwock has already been slain, Nyrissa has replaced it with the less dangerous but equally enormous sard from area @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]. In either case, the monstrous guardian won’t pursue foes into the House itself, but it will chase intruders for several minutes if they attempt to flee the region.

K3. Stables.name: K3. Stables
K3. Stables.text:
Six narrow stalls line the far wall of this stable.

Soon after the PCs enter, the unsettling sight of a dead horse hanging its head miserably over a stable door confronts them. Despite appearances, this is no undead horse. Rather, these six stalls each maintain a magical steed that can be “keyed” to a rider by simply opening the door to a stall and beckoning the undead-looking horse out. Each of these mounts function as a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WPKJOhEihhcIm2uQ] spell heightened to 6th level. The duration of the spell begins when a steed is removed from the stall, and a replacement steed appears here 4 hours after the previous one disappears.

K4. Lower Hall.name: K4. Lower Hall
K4. Lower Hall.text:
The polished marble floor of this otherwise empty chamber depicts a carving of the sun being devoured by a great dragon. The walls are painted to resemble a twilit forest with strange, dark shapes hiding amid the trees.

@UUID[Actor.m8kwG6NskYDlBSCy]

Moderate 19

The carving on the floor is harmless, but the dark shapes that seem to lurk amid the trees on the walls are not. These are powerful ankou assassins, guardians placed here by Nyrissa, eager to attack intruders and feel hot blood run over their dark talons. What Nyrissa doesn’t realize is that these ankous are in fact also spies for the Lantern King; if she manages to capture the Stolen Lands or reclaim Briar, the ankous abandon this area and return to their patron’s side to report. Otherwise, they’ll slip out of hiding among the shadows on the walls to attack as soon as anyone notices that they’re not merely decorations, or as soon as someone attempts to leave the room.

If an ankou assassin is reduced to fewer than 50 HP, it flees the House and does not return.

K5. Dining Room.name: K5. Dining Room
K5. Dining Room.text:
This dusty dining room seems to have been unused for decades. A huge wooden table fills the chamber, eight fine chairs drawn up to its sides. What appears to be a faintly glowing phantom meal is laid out on the table, and periodically bits of food or drink rise up and vanish as if being consumed by invisible diners. A statue of a beautiful woman stands in one corner of the room.

This feasting hall has not been used in centuries; the phantasmal food is an echo of the ancient past—the last time Nyrissa hosted a dinner party. The diners are not present, but the dinner moves and floats as if they are. Any PC who enters this room feels an urge to sit at the table to join the feast, but they can resist with ease. Those who do sit at the table and spend even a single action sampling the phantom food must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:39] save. On a success, the PC gains 30 temporary Hit Points and can immediately attempt a new saving throw against any ongoing disease or poison effect they are suffering against that affliction’s save; on a success, the affliction instantly ends. If the PC fails the Fortitude save from eating the phantasmal food, they instead become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR] (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR] on a critical failure) as the phantom food saps their life force. Once a PC has been affected by the food, they become immune to further effects from it. This phantasmal echo can be countered with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG] (9th-level effect, counteract DC 38).

@UUID[Actor.nNvJX0P2Tq2vsqX9]: The statue is a faithful rendition of the nymph Nyrissa but is otherwise unremarkable save for the magical cloak draped over its shoulders; it appears to be a cloak of the bat but is in fact a cursed type IV poisonous cloak.

K6. Dancing Bear.name: K6. Dancing Bear
K6. Dancing Bear.text:
This room is dominated by a domed cage, its verdigris-encrusted surface caked with muck. A taxidermy black bear stands lifelessly within.

The rubble-filled hall that leads to area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u] is treated as difficult terrain.

@UUID[Actor.sNqAajzeDA9BUkfa]

Simple Hazard 20

Moments after the PCs enter the chamber, the bear in the cage lumbers onto its hind legs and begins a slow but strangely graceful dance, made all the more grotesque by the fact that the bear is obviously dead and stuffed. One of Nyrissa’s many amusements, the bear is not undead but is a taxidermy animal rigged to serve as a dangerous trap against intruders. The bear itself is quite simple to destroy—indeed, this is part of the threat, for if it is destroyed, it explodes.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.yXcglgCpjOY1XpmL]

Causes the bear to disappear and scores the floors and walls of the room with burn marks.

K7. Observatory.name: K7. Observatory
K7. Observatory.text:
An arched opening looks out from the far side of this room, providing the large brass telescope in the middle of the room an excellent field of view.

The spyglass was used by Nyrissa to look at the stars and moon and planetary bodies beyond Thousandbreaths, but she hasn’t used the telescope in some time. The window itself is a one-way opening—it simply doesn’t exist on the outside. A character who climbs out the window can notice this strange quality with a @Check[type:perception|dc:30|traits:action:search] check, and as long as they retreat back into area K7 before fully exiting the House they can do so safely; otherwise, they’ll need to circle the manor to re-enter from the courtyard.

@UUID[Actor.yK2hg9pr3cypCPhy]: The telescope is quite heavy (80 pounds—8 Bulk) but quite valuable—it’s worth 3,500 gp.

K8. Storeroom.name: K8. Storeroom
K8. Storeroom.text:
What this oddly-shaped storeroom may have once held is impossible to tell, for its shelves today are empty.

While the room appears to be empty, success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:30|traits:action:search] check or a @Check[type:architecture-lore|dc:20|traits:action:investigate] check reveals that the shelves in the room seem to have been installed upside down.

In fact, the room itself is upside down, and anything that enters the room, be it a thrown coin or a PC or anything else, suddenly falls upward to the ceiling. This is hardly even a minor hazard for high-level PCs (it’s just a @Check[type:reflex|dc:15] save to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY] of the doorframe to avoid a fall for 5 points of damage), but it should serve as a dramatic reminder that not everything in the House is as it appears.

K9. The Swill Feast.name: K9. The Swill Feast
K9. The Swill Feast.text:
This was obviously some sort of dining room. A great oak table is pushed up against one wall while several rickety chairs line the opposite wall. The rotting remnants of a vast feast lie upon the table—silver tureens spill fungal rot, a tarnished silver salver lies ruptured on its side, and old bones cover a number of plates. The entire place reeks of garbage and decay.

@UUID[Actor.NMAvneOXrW7aRk1y]: This room is unremarkable, but if the silver service is cleaned, it’s worth 1,300 gp.

K10. Poisoned Well.name: K10. Poisoned Well
K10. Poisoned Well.text:
A covered well is this chamber’s only feature.

This well drops 100 feet into waters that, while cool and crystal clear, are tainted with disease—anyone who drinks from the well is exposed to an especially dangerous 20th-level strain of @UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH.Item.KtA9MV7RA5nWRmko], with a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:40] save).

K11. Teleporter Entrance.name: K11. Teleporter Entrance
K11. Teleporter Entrance.text:
This small chamber seems to have been decorated with an eye toward meditation. The themes herein are all of the natural world; a sumptuous stained glass window dominates the far wall, while six green candlesticks carved to look like writhing trees light the room. A large round dais of stone sits in one corner of the room.

Success at a DC 40 check made to Identify Magic while studying the stone dais reveals that it once functioned as a portal to come and go from the First World, but that functionality has been lost. Nonetheless, the dais does have a useful feature, for any attempt to teleport to this dais automatically bypasses the @UUID[.JcAvEG7qrQeNWnPF] that wards the House. Nyrissa isn’t aware of this strange side effect yet, but each time the PCs use this to teleport to area @UUID[.zsReYKTm9pOYrbYZ], roll a @Check[type:perception|dc:50] check for Nyrissa to determine if she notices the strange fluctuation in the House’s ambient magic. If she does, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.R9xqCBblkS5KE4y7] to order one of her minions to investigate—the Wriggling Man is the most likely choice. Once she’s made aware of what caused the fluctuation, Nyrissa manipulates the House’s magic; an hour later, this dais loses all magical properties, potentially setting up a shock to the PCs the next time they try to teleport to this room.

@UUID[Actor.38RAf2sgbE9Rn1kn]: The six intricately carved jade candlesticks are worth 5,000 gp each.

K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds.name: K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds
K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds.text:
This salon is decorated with vivid frescoes depicting primeval forests filled with floral blooms and beautiful women. Two plush sofas sit against the walls, while three low tables in the middle of the room hold beautiful floral arrangements. The sounds of some sort of celebration may be heard in this room as if from a great distance.

@UUID[Actor.MABh0eh1VKh3izdf]

Complex hazard 20

The faint sounds of celebration are phantoms and echoes from the past; the longer one remains in this room, the more the listener loses track of whether it’s the sounds themselves that are distant or if it’s themselves who are distant, being pushed away out of time and space by eldritch forces.

A PC who is under the protection of the Helix Theorem applies their +4 status bonus to all rolls and checks made against this hazard.

@UUID[Actor.PioS4R4ch9JWEsaw]: The decor in this room is elegant and impressive, but the expensive furniture decays to rot and mold if brought out of the room. Nonetheless, a 10-minute @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU] of the room and success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check are enough to discover a slender platinum flute under one of the sofa cushions. This flute is a greater maestro’s instrument.

K14. Hall of Weeping Demons.name: K14. Hall of Weeping Demons
K14. Hall of Weeping Demons.text:
This room is lined with strange, decaying plants. An empty pool sits in its center, and the walls are decorated with hundreds of small statues of sobbing demons.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.MkkASBpevcHthArx]}

Toggle the pool and flowers between empty and full.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]: Success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check notes that one of the hundreds of sobbing demons in fact appears to be laughing. Removing this demon from the shelf causes the plants in the room to bloom into life and the empty pool to fill with water as the weeping demon statues cry streams of real tears that run down to collect in the center of the room.

The pool takes 1 minute to fill completely, after which success on a DC 36 check to Identify Magic reveals its properties: The water casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.SnaLVgxZ9ryUFmUr] heightened to 6th level on anyone who steps into the pool, and also restores 150 HP. Each use causes the pool to shrink in size; there is enough water in the pool for three such uses.

The room “recharges” when the House resets, as long as Thousandbreaths hasn’t been uprooted—in this case, the room does not recharge once the pool’s three uses have been consumed.

K15. Servants’ Wing.name: K15. Servants’ Wing
K15. Servants’ Wing.text:
This wing of the House serves as workrooms for the servants. If the PCs enter this wing, they’ll quickly attract the anger of the wing’s guardians.

Area K15a was used for quick naps and relaxation. Area K15b, once used to arrange meals in pleasing presentations, is filled with rubble (this room is difficult terrain). Area K15c was used to prepare flower garlands, while area K15d was a parlor for discussing the day’s duties. Area K15e was the wing’s kitchen, while area K15f was used to store supplies. The servants themselves dined in area K15g, stored food and drink in area K15h, and kept preserved herbs and spices in area K15i—this last room also contains a trap door that opens at a touch (like the other doors in the complex) to reveal a ladder leading down to area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc].

@UUID[Actor.gXbDaY9ci2u22ptT]

Severe 19

No living servants remain here, but the wing is far from unoccupied. A group of a dozen ghostly guards can be found here, pantomiming various duties in the rooms. Areas K15c–K15e and K15h are each occupied by two ghosts. A group of three ghosts mime eating a meal in area K15g, while the final ghost apes the cataloging of herbs and spices in K15i.

As soon as any of these ghosts notice the PCs, they use their Frightful Moans to raise the alarm. This causes all the other ghosts in this wing to join the fight as soon as possible. If the Knurly Witch has retreated to area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc], she hears these howls and clambers up the ladder to join the fight as well. She makes good use of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wdA52JJnsuQWeyqz] to keep the ghosts healed.

K16. Cellar.name: K16. Cellar
K16. Cellar.text:
This earthen-floored cellar contains all manner of mundane supplies such as firewood, food, tools, lumber, and a surprising number of gourds drying on twine hanging from the rafters.

The cellar is split into three rooms, with the farthest from the ladder having been converted into a bedroom.

@UUID[Actor.SVUjDSZHYmwbQgnq]Low 19

This chamber is the home-away-from-home for the Knurly Witch when she visits the House—she chose this room out of all those offered her by Nyrissa because she likes the ambiance. If the Knurly Witch fled a previous encounter with the PCs, she can be found here nursing her wounds and her pride. If confronted here, she fights to the death.

K17. Throne Room.name: K17. Throne Room
K17. Throne Room.text:
Turquoise tiles adorn the walls of this chamber, with a false gallery hanging some ten feet above the tiled floor. An ornate wooden bridge crosses the chamber thirty feet above the floor, connecting doors on the building’s second floor—the vaulted ceiling rises another ten feet above that. Incredible paintings depicting animals in sylvan scenes cover this ceiling. The first shows a wolf in a forest with a severed hand clenched in its jaws. The second depicts a great viper approaching a crib, while the third shows a huge bear stalking a mother and child. An archway decorated with a dragon eating a mounted knight at one end of the room opens to a great iron spiral staircase leading upward, while at the other end of the hall sits a regal throne made of marble shot through with green veins. Two statues of beautiful women wielding upraised swords stand to either side of the throne, while a long purple carpet runs the length of the room. Numerous chairs and benches line the walls.

Nyrissa has not used this room in ages—her followers know what to do and there is little need for the nymph to address them. The stairs lead up to area @UUID[.xUo04MURzBvvjVcx], and the wooden bridge is area @UUID[.BERVHJyeUHv28SS3]. The walls can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy] with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30|traits:action:climb] check.

The throne is one of the four entrances to the Fable; it leads to area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK] (see that area for how one can enter the Fable via the throne).

With Nyrissa all but abandoning this room, its care has been entrusted to one of her most dangerous allies: her personal advisor, the Wriggling Man.

@UUID[Actor.NMCee869vhJjP5Ri]

Moderate 19

The Wriggling Man does not recall his life before his death and subsequent transformation into a worm that walks, save that he came to the First World on a long-forgotten mission. That he failed in this mission seems obvious, for it was after his failure and death that his mind and spirit infested the worms that fed upon his rotting remains and he was reborn as a worm that walks.

The Wriggling Man soon found work as Nyrissa’s advisor in all things arcane; while Nyrissa herself is a talented spellcaster, her gifts are inborn, not the result of study, and she appreciates help with her more complex plans. His aid has been instrumental in helping Nyrissa manipulate nascent kingdoms on hundreds of other worlds to prepare them for absorption into the Apology; currently, his only task is to await the PCs, ambush them, and kill them.

Warned by Nyrissa of the PCs’ approach as soon as they enter the House at the Edge of Time, the Wriggling Man has settled upon a cunning plan to both amuse himself and potentially disrupt the PCs’ plans. He casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Ucf8eynbZMfUucjE] on the northern end of the room to make it appear that the two statues of Nyrissa stand to either side of the throne rather than behind it, and includes a wall just behind the throne itself to completely obscure the northernmost five feet of the room. He then hides behind the throne north of the illusion to await the PCs’ arrival.

Effect

@UUID[Item.8wP9e8qQdrtTXYyk]

This effect changes the subject's token to that of an angelic being, and can be used to support the Wriggling Man's disguise.

As soon as he notices the PCs entering the chamber, he rolls for initiative using Stealth. On his turn, he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx], then casts veil to appear as an 8-foot-tall, Medium-sized angel with golden skin on the first of his three rounds. On the second round he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.yV7Ouzaoe7DHLESI], and on the third @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O] to make himself appear (as an angel) 30 feet south of the throne in the middle of the chamber.

When his time stop ends, the Wriggling Man, in his disguise, seems to appear out of nowhere in the middle of the room. He continues to sustain @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O] each round while remaining hidden behind the throne, and asks the PCs to stay their hands, hoping to trick them into thinking he’s actually an angelic guardian.

If the PCs hold off on attacking, the Wriggling Man imperiously informs the PCs that they must leave this House at once, lest they further intrude upon the works of one under the protection of Heaven itself. This is, of course, a lie—the Wriggling Man doesn’t expect the PCs to fall for it for long (if at all), but the tactic does amuse him. If the tactic works, he strings the PCs along with stories of how Heaven’s armies have come to the House at the Edge of Time to contain its dangers, and that from this point forward, no further action on the PCs’ behalf is needed to keep their kingdom safe. If the ruse works and the PCs leave, the Wriggling Man is somewhat surprised, but as soon as the PCs exit the room, he drops the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O], casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.VDudQ4x2ozosAbTb], and then follows them for a minute to make sure they leave. If they don’t, he’ll keep on them until they get into a fight or his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.VDudQ4x2ozosAbTb] is about to end, at which point he’ll join the battle to make things even more dangerous for the PCs.

If the PCs see through the ruse, though, the Wriggling Man is more than willing to fight. He continues to sustain his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O] as long as it makes sense to do so, casting offensive spells through the illusion as needed to fight the PCs. If his illusions are penetrated, he’ll work to avoid melee as best as he can, but if his magic incapacitates a character, he can’t resist approaching the poor PC to engulf them in his Squirming Embrace. He relies on his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WG91Z5TiR6oO5FOw] spell to rescue him if he gets into trouble; if he does manage to escape to area @UUID[.WvVPzlZL3XDYxu2f] he’ll remain away only as long as it takes for him to recover his health, at which point he @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vTQvfYu2llKQedmY] back into this room to track the PCs down and attack again—but this time he fights to the death.

K18. Dressing Chamber.name: K18. Dressing Chamber
K18. Dressing Chamber.text:
This dressing room has several wardrobes and long mirrors.

@UUID[Actor.kEIkoEde7PxQUIbG]: Long-neglected clothes fill the wardrobes. There are 20 noble outfits and a similar number of courtiers’ outfits. A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:perception|dc:30] check finds a beautiful platinum signet ring worth 1,500 gp in the pocket of one of the noble outfits.

K19. Ruined Washroom.name: K19. Ruined Washroom
K19. Ruined Washroom.text:
The walls of this forty-foot-high room have fractured, and whatever once decorated it now lies in pulverized fragments heaped in small drifts of sawdust and sand on the floor. This was clearly once some sort of washroom with stone walls and numerous tubs, but now the place is in a shambles.

When the House at the Edge of Time was created, the way it distorted and twisted time itself attracted the angry attention of a trio of bythos aeons, but when they arrived to oppose the construction of a structure that warped time and space, they ended up being trapped within it.

These same three aeons have remained trapped in this room ever since, and today they exist in a mindset simultaneously of initial fury at discovering the House and of someone who has been trapped in a room for centuries. Nyrissa and her minions avoid this room as a result.

@UUID[Actor.2evDJNdhsUEGe2w0]

Low 19

The aeons attack any intruders on sight. While they’re elite bythos aeons, they’re also limited by the nature of this room—they cannot leave the chamber by any means, including teleportation or planar travel. Worse, unlike other monsters in the House, these three aeons, thanks to their strange association with time itself, also reset whenever the House itself resets, and are restored to life as trapped as ever. Only if Nyrissa is defeated (either by killing her or forgiving her) will these three aeons ever escape.

Helix Theorem Feedback: A PC who is under the protection of the Helix Theorem adds their +4 status bonus from that to their Armor Class against these aeons, as each time the creatures attempt to attack such a PC, flashes of purple energy intervene with a gut-churning hum. The first time the bythos damages a PC who is protected by the Helix Theorem, the bythos must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:40] save. The bythos is then temporarily immune to this feedback for 1 hour.

  • Critical Success The aeon is unaffected by the feedback.

  • Success A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3].

  • Failure A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix].

  • Critical Failure A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be banished from the House at the Edge of Time.

Treasure: The aeons understand the cause of their freedom if the PCs defeat Nyrissa. They plane shift to Axis, but within a few days of Nyrissa’s defeat, they return to the Material Plane to thank the PCs with an envisioned explanation of the mercy the PCs granted them, along with an orichalcum weapon (choose a weapon used by one of the PCs who would most benefit from the weapon) before they return to Axis.

K20. The Dripping Clock.name: K20. The Dripping Clock
K20. The Dripping Clock.text:
A large and convoluted water clock built to look like a tree, constructed of darkwood, twisted crystal, and bronze tubes, drips quietly away in this dust-layered chamber. The walls of the room are given over to books—hundreds of them.

The clock continues to tick away the seconds, never losing time as it is inhabited and constantly tended and adjusted by a water mephit named Pludock. While the mephit would never dare to neglect his duty for fear of punishment, he’s a chatty creature and can be a useful source of information for the PCs. His initial attitude is indifferent. If made helpful, he happily talks with the PCs. He knows the secret of the healing pool in area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT] and the danger of damaging the dancing bear in area @UUID[.QPns9JfSg5Mf6rTK]; he might be able to inform the PCs of other minor traps or beneficial areas as well. If asked about Nyrissa, he grows silent after saying, “I’d better not say.” If forced into talking, he admits that she’s likely hiding out in the @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]—a chamber high above that allows her not only to manipulate things in the House but to watch over every room. When he says this, he clamps his hands over his mouth, his eyes bulge as he looks around at the corners of the room... and a moment later, he bursts into an explosion of water, slain by an unhappy Nyrissa via the Fable.

@UUID[Actor.KFf6pJmFmzj7HH9i]

Pludock has no desire for combat, but if he’s attacked by the party, he breathes acid to keep the PCs at bay, then flees shrieking through the House’s halls, shrieking and crying in panic the whole time.

L1. Great Hall.name: L1. Great Hall
L1. Great Hall.text:
This huge and ornate chamber has a vaulted ceiling, with supports carved to resemble serpentine dragons holding great beams aloft. Seven statues of a beautiful woman holding a sword, or posing in a seductive way, stand against the walls, along with several chairs and tables. Two long tables with benches sit in the middle of the room astride a large marble statue of a snakelike dragon.

This room serves as a grand banquet hall for when Nyrissa has enough guests to warrant such an occasion, although she hasn’t used it for this function since turning her attention to the Stolen Lands. The secret door to the servant’s wing can be found with success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check. It hasn’t been opened in ages and is somewhat stuck; succeeding at a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30] check is enough to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx].

@UUID[Actor.oM1AvORITfhzwrDk]

Low 19

A pair of Nyrissa’s pets, lithe and quick wyverns with long, barbed tongues capable of lashing out and pulling prey into their jaws, sleep and play in this chamber. If they sense intruders, they attack on sight, fighting to the death.

L3. Guest Rooms.name: L3. Guest Rooms
L3. Guest Rooms.text: This wing of the House contains four large guest rooms. None of these chambers have been used in a long time, but each seems brand new and ready to receive guests. Temporal ripples and phantoms sometimes flit around the place, echoes of long-departed guests. The PCs may well observe echoes of their own passage through these rooms—harmless but nonetheless disconcerting to see.

L4. Stairwell.name: L4. Stairwell
L4. Stairwell.text: This flight of spiral stairs leads up to area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg].

L6. Servants’ Wing.name: L6. Servants’ Wing
L6. Servants’ Wing.text: This wing of the House served as chambers for servants, but since Nyrissa created her ghostly guardians, these rooms have gone unused. Areas L6a and L6b are both bedrooms. L6c is a storeroom, while L6d is a privy. L6e is a lounge stocked with a large number of old (but relatively mundane and worthless) books, while L6f is an open room for exercise and gatherings.

L7. Throne Room Bridge.name: L7. Throne Room Bridge
L7. Throne Room Bridge.text:
This walkway crosses over the throne room (area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u]) below. The door to area @UUID[.2RWV0uhIckv9e10j] is one of the few that is kept locked. It is made of ironwood (Hardness 22, HP 100 [BT 50]) and it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:41|traits:action:force-open] (expert) check or its Lock can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H] with a @Check[type:thievery|dc:39|traits:action:pick-a-lock] (master) check.

Development: If the Wriggling Man has not yet been encountered, he’ll react to intruders on this bridge as detailed in area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u].

L8. Nyrissa’s Chambers.name: L8. Nyrissa’s Chambers
L8. Nyrissa’s Chambers.text:
This wing of the House contains Nyrissa’s private relaxation chambers, although since the beginning of this chapter, the nymph queen has spent her time in the Fable (area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]). All of the rooms in this wing are opulent and extravagant; the function of each is summarized below, but the area’s guardians are mobile and quickly react to intrusions, so combat here is likely to spill through multiple chambers.

Area L8a is a private ballroom, the walls of which are hung with floral tapestries. The connected washroom (area L8b) contains a porcelain tub that fills with hot, scented water on command. Area L8c is a study—a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU] of the room reveals several sheets bearing flowery script and illustrations of plant and fey creatures. Area L8d appears to be Nyrissa’s bedroom, but in fact the bed is one of the four entrances to the Fable—it leads to the nymph’s true bedroom (area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]; see that area for details on how to travel to the Fable). Area L8e is a drawing room, while area L8f is a large closet that contains the majority of Nyrissa’s impressive collection of clothing. Finally, area L8g is a combination reading room and lounge.

@UUID[Actor.rnFjLc6xYYPtXS6a]

Moderate 19

Although Nyrissa’s true valuables are kept elsewhere, enough remain here that she never leaves this suite of rooms unprotected. The safekeeping of these objects, the cleaning and tending of these rooms, and assisting Nyrissa (when she is present) are the duties of eight defaced naiad queens.

Nyrissa once counted these naiads her sisters and friends. Their beauty rivaled her own, but when Nyrissa suffered at the hands of the Eldest, these eight did as well when Nyrissa had the Nightmare Rook pluck out their eyes. These defaced naiads can still see and utilize their gaze attacks, but their beauty has been forever marred, and they spend their days in constant pain and servitude here. They know that Nyrissa is responsible for their unending pain, but they cannot bring themselves to hate her for it. When they notice intruders, they silently move to attack, tears of blood running freely down their cheeks.

@UUID[Actor.VGis5amG9jwiyW4l]: A Search of area L8a reveals a dozen different virtuoso handheld musical instruments, one of which is actually a horn of blasting.

@UUID[Actor.HMdrs7BdjxC5kU4z]: There are a total of 43 dresses in area L8f. 42 of them are worth 200 gp each; the other is actually an elegant (and scandalously cut) dress that duplicates the abilities of a neutral greater robe of the archmagi.

M1. Attic.name: M1. Attic
M1. Attic.text:
The wooden floor of this attic space is covered with thick layers of dust. Cobwebs hang in curtain-like sheets, and four skeletons slump against the southern wall. A ladder leads up to a trap door in the ceiling in one corner, with tendrils of thick roots pressing through around its edges from above.

The stairs lead down to area @UUID[.jYQkG4h3ci9x0cbG]. The trap door leads up to @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS] but is overgrown above by vines and roots, and as such must be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.IA0r4dD0J3R6SMxT]

Reveals the trapdoor hidden underneath the vines in area @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]

@UUID[Actor.M6RknN77XTo23v45]

Moderate 19

This room has long been abandoned. The skeletal remains are those of four powerful elven priestesses of Calistria, enemies Nyrissa captured and imprisoned after her first absorbed kingdom. Rather than transform into ghosts like the other heroes Nyrissa captured, these four priestesses became banshees after finally dying of old age in this room. They rise up instantly as soon as they notice intruders, and fight until destroyed, but even in undeath they cannot leave this room. Unlike the ghostly guards, their religious drive for vengeance has been only magnified in undeath, and as such they do not bear shame at their fate.

M2. Ivy Tower.name: M2. Ivy Tower
M2. Ivy Tower.text:
This tower looks out over the House grounds, leaning at a vertiginous angle over the courtyard below. The entire area has been covered completely with a nest-like tangle of vegetation.

A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check notes the vine- and root-covered trap door that leads down to area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg]. The ironwood vines that choke it must be cleared before the trap door can be opened easily; otherwise, it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx] with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check.

@UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]

Low 19

This tower’s open rooftop is the den of Nyrissa’s elite sard, a creature who takes up the entire space, its tangled roots hanging over the edges. It observes the PCs as they approach, even if they challenge foes down in the courtyard or atop the lower manor walls in areas @UUID[.COhCF3Ki8BXn1jLz]–@UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2], but it won’t join a fight there unless it is attacked. If someone forces open the trap door from area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg] below, they won’t be able to climb up onto the roof of the tower since the sard occupies that space completely, and the sard gets to roll Athletics for initiative as it shifts its bulk ponderously above. Once roused to anger, the monster pursues foes as best it can, either clambering over the House’s roofline or using its melee Strike’s reach to attack anyone who tries to retreat into area M1 for refuge. It abandons pursuit only if the PCs retreat deeper into the House or flee to the lake’s far shore; otherwise, it fights to the death.

If the PCs have slain the lesser jabberwock in @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt], Nyrissa relocates this sard down to area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2], in which case this area is empty.

M3. The Ruined Halls.name: M3. The Ruined Halls
M3. The Ruined Halls.text:
This series of rooms, once Nyrissa’s private sanctuary, suffered greatly from the nymph’s frustrations and wrath after she survived the Eldest’s attempt to have her killed by the Jabberwock, and as such serves as an exception to the rule elsewhere in the house that its nature has remained unchanged since its construction. She never bothered restoring these rooms and instead converted the suite at area @UUID[.2RWV0uhIckv9e10j] to serve as her new private quarters, leaving this area in shambles. Today these rooms are a tangle of thick, creeping vines and plants that have grown riotously to a height of two feet throughout the area, making this entire area greater difficult terrain. In addition, a large number of damaged or destroyed statues of all manner of creatures lie strewn about the place; these were left by this area’s dangerous guardian.

When Nyrissa first began experimenting with the jabberwock’s blood in her efforts to create a lesser version of the creature, one of her first attempts involved infusing creatures with the ichor. All but one of these experiments died, but the survivor, a medusa named Phomandala, transformed into a scaly but quite healthy monster with a pair of sizable cobras amid the smaller tangle of her serpentine hair. Phomandala has lived in these ruined halls ever since, serving as a guardian for the upper floors of the House. Over the years, the infusion of jabberwock blood and her life on the First World have slowly granted magical powers as well, and the medusa is now a powerful sorcerer in her own right. Her insights into the nature of primal magic have been a boon for Nyrissa as she continued to absorb kingdoms, helping her to refine the process of creating Blooms. For the last several dozen events on the last several dozen worlds, though, Phomandala has had little to do to further refine the process, and she has instead spent the past century or two in this suite of rooms enjoying a sort of “retirement”—relaxing among her statues, meditating, and carrying on long, complex discussions with visitors that often last for years. Her latest companions are a pair of capricious whimwyrms with whom Phomandala has been debating for almost the entire time this Adventure Path has taken place. With neither the medusa nor the whimwyrms budging on their positions regarding the role of chaos and law in the First World, they’ve largely not even noticed the advent of this latest round of Blooms.

  • @UUID[Actor.S4oIMaVPzQuRaTpK]
  • @UUID[Actor.SfFMqKTUQ1Dwu5lT]

Encounter

Moderate 19

When the PCs arrive, Phomandala doesn’t immediately attack. Instead, she asks the PCs what their take is on the role of law and chaos in the First World. If the PCs react in a way that favors law, she smirks in delight and the whimwyrms attack in anger, but if the PCs react in a way that favors chaos, she shrieks in frustration and attacks instead. Regardless, once the second round of combat begins, the nonparticipant joins in the fight against the PCs. If the PCs attempt to argue that law and chaos are equally important, the medusa and the whimwyrms all attack on the first round.

Strategy: Phomandala avoids melee if possible, using her spells and Focused Gaze against PCs while relying on her ability to move through the room’s difficult terrain with ease to stay out of melee. The whimwyrms open with their breath weapons, then move in to fight in melee. If both whimwyrms are slain, Phomandala uses @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.HpIJTVqgXorH9X0L] to return them to the fight. All three fight to the death, in any event, frustrated at having their debate interrupted when it felt like it was only a few more months away from a proper resolution.

M4. Nyrissa’s Library.name: M4. Nyrissa’s Library
M4. Nyrissa’s Library.text:
This room is both a laboratory and a library, with numerous large tomes sitting on sagging shelves along the walls and several tables covered with notes and strange schematics.

The majority of the notes on the tables are poetry written by Nyrissa, but if the PCs have unanswered questions about what Nyrissa is up to or why she’s out to take the Stolen Lands, they can discover fragmentary notes here to help clear up any lingering last-minute questions that you know don’t hinge on the events of @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs]. The PCs can also learn about the Fable by studying these notes. A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:nature|dc:30|traits:action:investigate] check or a @Check[type:arcana|dc:40], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:investigate], or @Check[type:religion|dc:40|traits:action:investigate] check made as part of an hour spent @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EwgTZBWsc8qKaViP] these notes learns not only what the Fable is capable of and how it works, but also the locations of the four portals that open into the Fable. Such a character also learns the method of opening the portals, as well as the method of leaving the Fable once one is inside it. See area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK] for these details. If the PCs aren’t stealthy about investigating these notes, Nyrissa may notice them from her vantage point in the Fable and alert any surviving minions to make all haste to this area to stop the PCs from learning too much from these carelessly forgotten notes.

@UUID[Actor.qvgVySLNYbyKY0Y7]: This library contains a large number of books about the First World, the Stolen Lands, and magic theory.
